examples.en: I have never been abroad.
examples.ja: 未だ海外に行ったことが有りません。

examples.en: It is still unknown where my husband is.
examples.ja: 主人がどこにいるのか、未だ不明です。

examples.en: I bet no one has lived up to 200 years old.
examples.ja: 未だ、二百才まで生きた人はいないでしょう。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the adverb version of <kanji>未</kanji>, so it means the same thing: <vocabulary>not yet</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>still</vocabulary>, depending on the context.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn it with this kanji, so here a mnemonic to help you:

Someone's telling you "<vocabulary>not yet</vocabulary>... not yet.... not yet...". You have some food on your nose, but you're not allowed to eat it <reading>今</reading> (いま).

Note that this word can also be read まだ. However, いまだ is often written in kanji, while まだ is almost always written in kana. So when you see 未だ, it's a safe bet to read it as いまだ!

examples.en: How about setting more specific criteria for your goals?
examples.ja: もう少し、目標に具体的な規準を設定してみてはいかがでしょうか。

examples.en: Can you teach me how to create evaluation criteria?
examples.ja: 評価規準の作成方法を教えてもらえませんか？

examples.en: Based on this condition, it does not meet the selection criteria.
examples.ja: この条件だと、選考規準に満たないですね。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>standard</kanji> of <kanji>standard</kanji>s is the main <vocabulary>criterion</vocabulary> we work off of. That’s the <vocabulary>standard</vocabulary> we follow.

Compared to 基準 that's often a quantitative "standard" for assessment, 規準 is more of a quality-focused "criterion" that can be a basis for goals. You'll often see this word used in academic or professional contexts.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Although they’re not official readings, people sometimes distinguish 基準 and 規準 by calling them もとじゅん and のりじゅん respectively when speaking.

examples.en: However, it should be noted that the limit is set at one million yen per person.
examples.ja: ただし、一人当たり１００万円を限度とする。

examples.en: Even though you are generous, there is a limit.
examples.ja: いくら気前がよくても限度というものがある。

examples.en: I forget what my limit is on this credit card.
examples.ja: このクレジットカードの限度額がいくらだったか忘れちゃったんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
A certain <kanji>limit</kanji>’s <kanji>degree</kanji> is how far it can go. It’s the <vocabulary>limit</vocabulary>; turn it up one more degree and it’s out of <vocabulary>bounds</vocabulary>. Keep it right where it is and it’s perfect.

This word refers to the maximum extent or range of something, beyond which it cannot be surpassed. While similar to 限界, 限度 often implies a predetermined acceptable or tolerable limit, while 限界 is more closely associated with an absolute or ultimate limit.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: You can see the whole city from here.
examples.ja: ここから、町の全景が見わたせるんです。

examples.en: If you have a drone, you can take a picture of the whole city!
examples.ja: ドローンがあれば、この都市の全景を写した写真がとれますよ！

examples.en: Well, I can't get a good picture of the whole building from this information.
examples.ja: うーん、この情報だけだと、建物の全景がうまくイメージできないな。

examples.en: I was expecting a breathtaking panorama of Mt. Fuji, but the reality of it was pretty pathetic.
examples.ja: 私は息を飲むような富士の全景を期待していたが、実際はかなりお粗末なものだった。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you can see <kanji>all</kanji> the <kanji>scene</kanji> you have a <vocabulary>complete view</vocabulary>.

This is not a common word in everyday conversations, but it can be found in literature, art, film, photography, and travel writing to describe a panoramic or comprehensive view of a scene.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I’ll blur the foreground a bit.
examples.ja: 前景をちょっとぼかしてみます。

examples.en: Can you make this foreground layer invisible?
examples.ja: この前景レイヤー、見えなくしてみて。

examples.en: Isn't the tree standing in the foreground too prominent?
examples.ja: 前景に立っている木、目立ちすぎじゃない？

examples.en: How can I focus on something in the foreground with this camera?
examples.ja: このカメラでは、どうすれば前景の被写体にピントを合わせることができるんですか？

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>front</kanji> <kanji>scene</kanji> is the <vocabulary>foreground</vocabulary>.

This word primarily refers to the visual foreground in art, photography, or theater. Unlike "foreground" in English, it’s not commonly used in a figurative sense to describe the most prominent aspect of situations.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The man, though staggering, began to slowly walk once again.
examples.ja: 男はよろめきながらも、再びゆっくりと歩き始めた。

examples.en: I didn't think I would end up visiting this place again.
examples.ja: この地を再び訪れることになるとは思ってもいなかったよ。

examples.en: The next morning, the monster appeared again.
examples.ja: 次の朝、怪物は再び現れた。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is the adverb version of 再, so it shares the meaning <vocabulary>again</vocabulary> and also has the meaning <vocabulary>once again</vocabulary>.

Note that this word is somewhat formal and literary.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>Once again</vocabulary>, you have to say "<reading>Who</reading>? <reading>Ta</reading>-<reading>ta</reading>!" (ふたた). That's because people you don't know keep trying to talk to you, <vocabulary>again</vocabulary> and again. Whenever this happens you say "Who? Ta-ta!" again and run away.

examples.en: The sports festival is not this week, but the week after next.
examples.ja: 運動会は今週じゃなくて再来週だよ。

examples.en: What's the plan for the week after next?
examples.ja: 再来週の予定ってどんな感じ？

examples.en: Would it be possible to reschedule lunch for the week after next?
examples.ja: ランチ、再来週にリスケできないかな？

meaning_mnemonic: You know how 来週 is <kanji>next week</kanji>? Well, if you do next week again, you have the <vocabulary>week after next</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Therefore, this medication became known to the people.
examples.ja: 故に、この薬は人々に知られるようになったのです。

examples.en: As a consequence of being good-looking, people tend to only look at my face. I used to dislike it, but now I accept it as the fate that comes with being a beautiful woman.
examples.ja: 私は美人が故に顔ばかり見られます。以前は嫌だったんですが、今は美人が故の宿命だと思って受け入れています。

examples.en: "Why do you humans suffer?" "It is because of love that humans must suffer."
examples.ja: 「何が故にソナタたち人間は苦しむのじゃ？」「愛故に人は苦しまねばならぬのだ」

examples.en: I was repeatedly late without permission and consequently my vacation days were cut short.
examples.ja: 度重なる無断遅刻故に、 休暇日数が減らされてしまった。

meaning_mnemonic:
You learned that 故 means reason. Basically, whatever comes before 故に in a statement is going to be the reason for something that comes after. So 故に works like <vocabulary>therefore</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>consequently</vocabulary>. It can also be translated as "because" or other similar conjunctions depending on the context.

Also keep in mind that 故に is mainly used in formal contexts, like in academic writing or politicians' speeches — just like "therefore" in English.
reading_mnemonic:
By knowing the word 故 you'll know the reading for this word too! Here's a mnemonic in case you need a reminder, though:

You're using WaniKani, <vocabulary>therefore</vocabulary> you're studying kanji and vocab. Whose fault is it? It's WaniKani's fault! But, your brain has been beaten to a mush from all the studying, so when you say "it's your fault" it comes out as "it's <reading>yue</reading> fault!" Go ahead and say it out loud that way.

examples.en: The wire was on the floor, you know.
examples.ja: 針金が床に落ちていたよ。

examples.en: Let's use a wire to fasten it.
examples.ja: 針金を使って留めましょう。

examples.en: This is art made by bending hanger wire.
examples.ja: これはハンガーの針金を曲げて作ったアートです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>needle</kanji> made of <kanji>gold</kanji> is a <vocabulary>wire</vocabulary>. Perhaps wires were made from gold mostly back in the day? And they were thin like needles? That's my guess.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading of both. You already know both of these, just watch out for the rendaku on 金!

examples.en: What a huge green bell pepper!
examples.ja: なんて巨大なピーマンなんだ！

examples.en: A gigantic Tofugu doll has arrived in the office.
examples.ja: 巨大なトーフグ人形がオフィスに届きました。

examples.en: There is a possibility of a huge earthquake, like one from the Nankai Trough occurring while you are traveling in Japan, right?
examples.ja: 日本に旅行してる時に、南海トラフみたいな巨大地震が来る可能性もあるでしょ？

examples.en: I strongly suggest that you schedule the appointment with him well in advance because he is the president of an enormous company and he is very, very busy.
examples.ja: 彼はとっても忙しい巨大企業の社長さんなんだから、アポの約束は絶対に早目に取っておいた方がいいよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>giant</kanji> <kanji>big</kanji> thing is something that is <vocabulary>huge</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>gigantic</vocabulary>.

巨大 is often used in writing to describe something <vocabulary>enormous</vocabulary>. It can be for anything of immense scale, not just physical objects like buildings or monsters, but also abstract things like the impact of a natural disaster or even a person's influence.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: To insects, humans are giants, right?
examples.ja: 虫にとっては、人間も巨人でしょ。

examples.en: What, are you a Giants fan?
examples.ja: えっ、巨人ファンなんですか？

examples.en: That basketball player has gigantism.
examples.ja: あのバスケットボール選手は巨人症です。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>giant</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is <vocabulary>a giant</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: We plan to invite a hundred clients to this party.
examples.ja: 今回のパーティーには、クライアントを百名招く予定です。

examples.en: It's called "beckoning" to use your hands to invite people in.
examples.ja: 人を手を使って招くことを「手招きする」って言うんですよ。

examples.en: It would be great if we could invite him as our CEO.
examples.ja: 彼をうちのCEOとして招くことができれば最高なんだけどな。

examples.en: Eh, I thought it was the weak yen that causes inflation, but a strong yen can also cause inflation sometimes?
examples.ja: え、インフレを招くのは円安だと思ってたんですが、円高がインフレを招くこともあるんですか？

examples.en: I wrote a song to summon the spirits of the dead.
examples.ja: 死者の霊魂を招く歌を作ってみた。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>beckon</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to beckon</vocabulary>. 

Since 招く conjures up the image of someone beckoning, it also means <vocabulary>to invite</vocabulary>, and is a relatively formal word. Figuratively, it can also mean <vocabulary>to cause</vocabulary>, as in inviting some undesirable outcome or situation.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You move <vocabulary>to beckon</vocabulary> your friend over. You can't see him well, so that's why you invite him to come closer. He is hiding something, and it turns out to be his long, luxurious horse <reading>mane</reading> (まね). Why does he have a mane!? Horse steroids?

meanings: To Reach The Peak Of Something

examples.en: Koichi went to Japan to attend a kanji dojo to master the art of kanji.
examples.ja: コウイチは漢字の道を極めるために、日本に行って漢字道場に通いました。

examples.en: I'm a master at cheesecake, you know.
examples.ja: 私、チーズケーキは極めてるからさ。

examples.en: It is no easy task to master the Japanese language.
examples.ja: 日本語を極めるのは、生易しい事ではない。

examples.en: Due to the bad weather, the rescue operation became extremely challenging.
examples.ja: 天候が悪かったので、レスキュー作業は困難を極めました。

examples.en: My dream was to enter the legal profession and master the law, but I've just become extremely busy with work.
examples.ja: 法律関係の職に就いて法律を極めることが夢でしたが、それよりも仕事で多忙を極めることになりました。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji itself means <kanji>extreme</kanji>. The verb vocab version isn't "to extreme" because that wouldn't make sense. Instead, you bring something to extremes, making this <vocabulary>to reach the peak of something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to perfect</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to reach the extreme</vocabulary>.

極める commonly means reaching the highest level of proficiency or excellence in a particular skill, art, or field. It can also mean taking something to the extreme, like being crazy busy.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you go <vocabulary>to reach the peak of something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to perfect</vocabulary> something, you tend to go a little overboard, so there has to be a <reading>key</reading> <reading>wo</reading>rd (きわ) that other people can say to remind you to calm down a little. “PINEAPPLE! PINEAPPLE!”

examples.en: It's too early to retire from active duty.
examples.ja: 現役を退くには、まだ早過ぎますよ。

examples.en: The player chose to retire from the front lines and become a coach.
examples.ja: その選手は第一線を退いて、コーチになる道を選びました。

examples.en: Facing the wolf, Mika retreated two or three steps back.
examples.ja: オオカミを前にして、ミカは二、三歩退いた。

examples.en: How do you think you would have gotten the enemy soldiers to retreat in this situation?
examples.ja: お前なら、どうすればこの状況で敵兵を退かせることができると思う？

examples.en: Koichi finished his term and stepped down from the position of president.
examples.ja: コウイチは任期を満了し、大統領の座を退きました。

examples.en: Even after you resign from your position, you must not disclose or misuse personal information obtained in the course of your work.
examples.ja: 職を退いた後も、仕事で得た個人情報を他人にもらしたり、悪用してはいけません。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>retreat</kanji>, and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to retreat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to withdraw</vocabulary>.

退く can also mean <vocabulary>to resign</vocabulary>, since resigning is a kind of a figurative retreat, like from a professional role or the forefront of some field or industry.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You need <vocabulary>to retreat</vocabulary> because <reading>she re-zo</reading>ned (しりぞ) where you are standing. Now this is a no standing zone. Who is she? The re-zoner, duh.

examples.en: Please follow the arrows.
examples.ja: 矢印にそって進んでください。

examples.en: What does the arrow road sign mean?
examples.ja: あの矢印の道路標識は何という意味ですか。

examples.en: How do you make the arrow symbols appear?
examples.ja: 矢印ってどうやって出すの？

examples.en: The blue arrow road sign means "left turn allowed," and the sign with a white arrow on a blue background means "one-way"!
examples.ja: 青い矢印の標識は「左折可」で、青地に白抜きの矢印の標識「一方通行」だよ！

meaning_mnemonic: 矢印 combines the kanji <kanji>arrow</kanji> and the vocab word 印 (mark), giving us the type of arrow you use for pointing at things, like these: →↑↓←. It could be an arrow on a sign, or on a piece of paper, or a document. We can just call it an <vocabulary>arrow</vocabulary>, or an <vocabulary>arrow symbol</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 矢 and 印 put together into one. The 印 is like the actual vocab word 印, but watch out for rendaku changing it from しるし to じるし.

examples.en: Today at school we learned about series circuits and parallel circuits.
examples.ja: 今日は学校で、直列回路と並列回路について学びました。

examples.en: At that station, the express train and local train were stopped side by side.
examples.ja: その駅では、特急電車と各駅電車が並列して停車していた。

examples.en: I am not good at doing multiple things simultaneously, like doing housework while watching TV...
examples.ja: 私はテレビを見ながら家事をしたり…みたいなマルチタスクの並列処理が苦手です。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Line up</kanji> everything in a <kanji>row</kanji>. When you do that, they're all in <vocabulary>parallel</vocabulary>.

並列 is specifically used to describe items being arranged in a parallel way, like in parallel circuits or when vehicles are parked parallel to each other.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm not good at doing things in parallel.
examples.ja: 私、並行して何かをするのは苦手なんです。

examples.en: I am currently writing two novels at the same time.
examples.ja: 今、二つの小説を同時並行で書いています。

examples.en: I like the scene where the train runs parallel with the bicycle, along a section of track that's side by side with the road.
examples.ja: 線路と道路が並行している区間を、電車と自転車が並行して走るシーンが好きなんです。

examples.en: I heard that studying multiple languages at the same time is more efficient than only studying one.
examples.ja: 複数の言語を並行して勉強することは、ひとつだけを学習するよりも効率的だと聞いたことがあります。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Line up</kanji> and <kanji>go</kanji> together. If you did that, you'd be <vocabulary>in parallel</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>going abreast</vocabulary> with someone.

並行 refers to two or more things placed or moving parallel to each other, like buses or trains running side by side. It's also used to describe two or more activities happening at the same time.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I can’t believe that people wait in line for twelve hours just to get some eco-friendly bags.
examples.ja: エコバッグを買うために十二時間も行列に並ぶなんて信じられないよ。

examples.en: It's dangerous, so please line up inside the white line.
examples.ja: 危ないですから白線の内側にお並びください。

examples.en: Please don't push in. We were here first. Everybody is waiting in line, so you should take your place in the queue like everyone else too. The end of the line is that way.
examples.ja: 割りこまないで下さい。私達が先ですよ。みんな並んでいるんですから、あなたもちゃんと並ぶべきです。列の最後尾はあちらです。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji itself means <kanji>line up</kanji>, and this is the intransitive verb version of that, which makes this <vocabulary>to line up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be lined up</vocabulary>. You can remember this because you keep saying <reading>boo</reading> (ぶ), why is everyone already lined up? If you were the one in charge of lining things up, you wouldn't have <vocabulary>to stand in line</vocabulary> yourself…

Figuratively, this can also mean <vocabulary>to be on par</vocabulary>, as in someone or something matches or is comparable in ability, status, or ranking to another (as if they are aligned side by side in comparison).
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Only for you, when you visit <reading>Nara</reading> (なら), the deer there are <vocabulary>to be lined up</vocabulary> for you to inspect, as you are the deer inspector. If you don't know about Nara and its deer, you should look it up, they're pretty awesome.

examples.en: We have an ordinary and a luxury makizushi set. Which one would you like?
examples.ja: この巻きずしセット、並と上があるんだけど、どっちがいい？

examples.en: You can't achieve this level of success with just ordinary effort.
examples.ja: 並の努力では、ここまで成功することはできないよ。

examples.en: He had average reflexes, but a great mind.
examples.ja: 運動神経は並だったが、頭はすこぶる良かった。

meaning_mnemonic:
The things that <kanji>line up</kanji> are <vocabulary>ordinary</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>average</vocabulary> things. Because the majority of things (or people) fall into the average category, you could say most of them line up side by side with each other.

This might be why 並 is often used in restaurants to refer to standard (or average) portion sizes. And in sushi restaurants, 並 can refer to a standard set, as opposed to a more luxurious or premium one.

Note that when describing something as 並 outside of a restaurant or commercial context, it could have a slightly judgmental tone. Most people wouldn't love it if you called their work (or them) ordinary and average, you know?
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:

You're at the coast, looking out at the <reading>波</reading> (なみ), which are all very <vocabulary>ordinary</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>average</vocabulary>. Nothing exceptional about those waves.

examples.en: I'm planning to go to university again and earn a master's degree properly.
examples.ja: もう一度大学に行って、ちゃんと修士の学位を取るつもりなんです。

examples.en: I'm studying to get my master's degree while working part time.
examples.ja: アルバイトをしながら、修士号を取るために勉強しています。

examples.en: Last year, I completed my master's degree in applied linguistics.
examples.ja: 昨年、応用言語学の修士課程を修了しました。

meaning_mnemonic: A degree of <kanji>mastering</kanji> equal to a <kanji>samurai</kanji> is required for a <vocabulary>master's degree</vocabulary>. You'll have to master your chosen skill to the level of a samurai in order to obtain such a degree… Sounds tough.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I don't know how to repair clocks.
examples.ja: 時計の修理の仕方が分かりません。

examples.en: If you send it in for repair, won't the repair cost a lot of money?
examples.ja: 修理に出したら、修理代、高くつくんじゃない？

examples.en: I contacted the manufacturer, but they said they no longer have the parts and it is beyond repair.
examples.ja: メーカーに問い合わせましたが、もう部品がなく修理不能だそうです。

examples.en: "Hey, repairman. Can you fix this right now?" "You mean, you guys' relationship? Sorry. No can do."
examples.ja: 「おい、修理屋。これはすぐに直せるか？」「って、君たちの関係ってこと？悪いけど、それはできないよ。」

examples.en: Why don't you bring an umbrella?

reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I left the restaurant, forgetting my umbrella in the stand where I had placed it.

meaning_mnemonic: This is when you take your <kanji>umbrella</kanji> and you <kanji>stand</kanji> it up. Wait, how is an umbrella standing up? Good question, my dear Crabling, you are putting your umbrella in an <vocabulary>umbrella stand</vocabulary>.

examples.en: My sister works at a children's welfare center.
examples.ja: 私の姉は、児童相談所で働いています。

examples.en: Isn't Harry Potter a children's book? I always thought it was a book aimed at children.
examples.ja: ハリー・ポッターって、児童書じゃないの？てっきり児童向けの本だと思っていたよ。

examples.en: Recently, there has been an increase in the number of students wandering about during class.
examples.ja: 最近、授業中に立ち歩く児童生徒が増えています。

examples.en: Ninety percent of the children were absent.
examples.ja: 児童の九割が欠席しました。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>child</kanji> who is a <kanji>juvenile</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>child</vocabulary>. A group of them is <vocabulary>children</vocabulary>.

児童 refers specifically to children who are of elementary school age, typically from around 6 to 12 years old. It's often used in formal contexts, like in legal documents or when referring to <vocabulary>school children</vocabulary> in educational settings.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Early childhood is a special time, and early childhood education is very important.

examples.en: It's really cute when toddlers speak toddler language!
examples.ja: 幼児が幼児語しゃべってるのって、本当に可愛いよね！

meaning_mnemonic:
An <kanji>infancy</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> is a <vocabulary>toddler</vocabulary>. The kanji are kind of deceptive since this isn't really used for infants. It's more for small children, from toddlers on up to <vocabulary>preschooler</vocabulary>s.

幼児 is sort of formal, but it's commonly used to talk about small children from about one to six years old, or about that specific period of early childhood.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Misaki's hands are so cold!
examples.ja: ミサキちゃんの手、めっちゃ冷たいね！

examples.en: You should eat the soup soon, or it will end up cold.
examples.ja: 早く飲まないと、スープが冷たくなっちゃうよ。

examples.en: We call cold coffee "ice coffee" in Japanese.
examples.ja: 冷たいコーヒーのことを、日本語では「アイスコーヒー」と呼びます。

examples.en: I may sound cold, but I'm under tight control from above, and that makes many things difficult.
examples.ja: 冷たいことを言うようですが、こちらも上からの締めつけがきびしくて色々と難しいんです。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>cool</kanji> is <vocabulary>cold</vocabulary>. This refers to something that is <vocabulary>cold to the touch</vocabulary>, not the weather or something like that (which is 寒い).
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's mnemonic to help you: Something that is really <vocabulary>cold</vocabulary> to the touch is cold enough <reading>to ma</reading>ke ice cream with.

examples.en: I tried to speak in as calm a tone as possible.
examples.ja: できるだけ冷静な口調で話すようにした。

examples.en: Let's calm down! Let's compose ourselves a bit.
examples.ja: 落ち着いて！ちょっと冷静になろう。

examples.en: How can you stay calm after something like this?
examples.ja: こんなことが起きて、冷静でいられる訳がないだろ！

meaning_mnemonic: You're <kanji>cool</kanji> and <kanji>quiet</kanji>. That's you, daddio. Nice and <vocabulary>cool-headed</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>calm</vocabulary>. So much <vocabulary>composure</vocabulary>
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Our freezer is always full.
examples.ja: うちの冷凍庫はいつもいっぱいなんです。

examples.en: Geez, I forgot to close the freezer!
examples.ja: げっ、冷凍庫、閉め忘れてた！

examples.en: I hope you find a good freezer.
examples.ja: 良い冷凍庫が見つかるといいですね。

examples.en: There is a mysterious block in our freezer. What is that?
examples.ja: 冷凍庫の中に怪しいカタマリが入っているんだけど、あれ何？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>cool</kanji> <kanji>frozen</kanji> <kanji>storage</kanji> is one which is really cold on the inside, so cold it can freeze things. This is called a <vocabulary>freezer</vocabulary>, not to be confused with 冷蔵庫, which is refrigerator, and doesn't have the kanji for "freeze" in it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Do soap bubbles freeze?
examples.ja: シャボン玉って凍るの？

examples.en: If it’s venison, I have it frozen in the freezer.
examples.ja: シカ肉なら、冷凍庫で凍らせてあるよ。

examples.en: Have you ever made ice cubes by freezing orange juice?
examples.ja: オレンジジュースを凍らせて氷を作ったことはありますか。

examples.en: Please be careful because the road is still frozen solid.
examples.ja: 道路はまだガチガチに凍ってるから気を付けてね。

examples.en: I was really horrified. It was a spine-chilling experience.
examples.ja: ほんと、ゾッとしましたよ。背筋が凍る思いでした。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>frozen</kanji>, so the vocab version is <vocabulary>to freeze</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading actually comes from the word 氷, which means "ice." You can kind of see where the origins of these words come from, now... really cold frozen things. So, think back to こおり, then change the り to a る and put it outside the kanji. That makes the reading for this <reading>こお</reading>る, in all (or most) of 氷's glory.

examples.en: A rat was frozen to death in a kennel.
examples.ja: 犬小屋でネズミが凍死していました。

examples.en: If you leave it outside on this cold day, it might freeze to death, don't you think?
examples.ja: こんなに寒い日に外に放置していると、凍死しちゃうんじゃない？

examples.en: In Germany, shelter pods are placed in various parts of town to prevent homeless people from freezing to death.
examples.ja: ドイツでは、ホームレスが凍死しないように、町の色々なところにシェルターポッドが配置されています。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>frozen</kanji> <kanji>death</kanji> isn't a bad way to go, I hear. Still, you don't want to <vocabulary>freeze to death</vocabulary> if you can help it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My account has been frozen.
examples.ja: アカウントが凍結されちゃいました。

examples.en: It might not be completely frozen yet, so be careful.
examples.ja: まだ完全には凍結していないかもしれないから、気を付けてね。

examples.en: We spread salt on the roads to prevent freezing.
examples.ja: 凍結防止のために道に塩をまきます。

examples.en: She often complains about frozen roads.
examples.ja: 彼女は道路の凍結についてよく文句を言っています。

meaning_mnemonic:
Things that are <kanji>frozen</kanji> have been <kanji>tie</kanji>d up in <vocabulary>freezing</vocabulary> ice. They <vocabulary>get frozen</vocabulary> that way. 

凍結 is a relatively formal word that is used for the physical freezing of infrastructure, such as roads and water pipes. It can also refer to the freezing of systems or accounts, like the suspension of social media or bank accounts.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: He complains that his boss doesn't deal with clients' complaints.
examples.ja: 彼は、上司が顧客のクレーム処理をしないことについてぶつぶつ文句を言っている。

examples.en: My computer couldn't process the data and froze.
examples.ja: パソコンがデータを処理しきれずにフリーズしてしまった。

examples.en: That player is good at taking care of ground balls.
examples.ja: あの選手はゴロを処理するのが上手い。

meaning_mnemonic:
I can <kanji>deal with</kanji> it, no matter what the <kanji>reason</kanji>. I swear I can <vocabulary>deal with</vocabulary> this problem on my own!

処理 is a relatively formal word for <vocabulary>handling</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>processing</vocabulary> a problem or task to bring it to a resolution. It covers all kinds of tasks, from administrative work and data processing to practical challenges like waste disposal and complaint handling. It can even apply to defusing unexploded bombs.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I disposed of all the things I don't need.
examples.ja: いらないものを全部処分しました。

examples.en: I went to the final clearance sale for summer items.
examples.ja: 夏物の最終処分セールに行ってきました。

examples.en: The company I had invested in suddenly received an administrative penalty, and its stock price plummeted.
examples.ja: 投資していた企業が、突然行政処分を受けることになり、株価が急落しました。

examples.en: My son was expelled from school for bullying a student.
examples.ja: 私の息子は、ある生徒にイジメを行い、退学処分を受けました。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>deal with</kanji> trash, you have to <kanji>divide</kanji> it into different types before you can get to its <vocabulary>disposal</vocabulary>. Whenever you deal with and divide something, you’re preparing to dispose of it.

処分 means getting rid of things you don’t want, like trash or old furniture. Sometimes, it can also mean <vocabulary>punishment</vocabulary>, like suspension from school for breaking the rules. This connection makes sense because both disposal and punishment involve handling something unwanted—whether it's an item or a behavior.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: At the pharmacy, I got a discount coupon.
examples.ja: 薬局で、割引券をもらいました。

examples.en: I have an extra movie ticket, would you like it?
examples.ja: 映画の券が余ってるんだけど、よかったらいらない？

examples.en: Can I get a commuter pass for three consecutive months?
examples.ja: 三ヶ月の定期券をもらえますか？

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

券 is a standalone word that means <vocabulary>ticket</vocabulary>, but it's commonly used as a suffix to form words like 入場券 (admission ticket), 割引券 (discount <vocabulary>coupon</vocabulary>), or 定期券 (commuter <vocabulary>pass</vocabulary>).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Usually it's attached to things, because it tells you what kind of ticket something is.

examples.en: The new passport should have a new passport number as well.
examples.ja: 新しいパスポートは、旅券番号も新しくなるはずだよ。

examples.en: I'd like to leave my passport in the hotel safe.
examples.ja: ホテルの金庫に旅券を入れてもらいたいのですが。

examples.en: There are two types of passports: those valid for ten years and those valid for five years.
examples.ja: 旅券には有効期間が十年のものと五年のものの二種類があります。

examples.en: In case of an emergency, please make a photocopy of your passport ahead of time and store it separately from your passport while at your destination.
examples.ja: 万が一のために、旅先ではあらかじめ旅券のコピーをとり、旅券とは別の場所に保管するようにしてください。

meaning_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>trip</kanji> <kanji>ticket</kanji> is the ticket that lets you go on ALL of your trips. It's not your airplane ticket, it's not your boat ticket, it's the trip ticket. It's your <vocabulary>passport</vocabulary>, which allows you to take trips.

旅券 is a formal term for a passport. It's commonly used in official documents and formal settings, like when dealing with government paperwork. In less formal contexts, you can simply say パスポート!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Where can I buy advance tickets?
examples.ja: 前売り券はどこで買えるんですか？

examples.en: I got two advance tickets for a movie. Would you like to come with me?
examples.ja: 映画の前売り券を二枚もらったんだけど、よかったらいっしょに行かない？

examples.en: If there are no discounts or special offers, what's the point of buying advance tickets?
examples.ja: ディスカウントも特典もないんなら、前売り券を買う意味なくない？

examples.en: It says that tickets sold in advance can't be used with other discounts.
examples.ja: 前売り券は他の割引とは併用できませんって書いてあるよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
What's a <kanji>before</kanji> <kanji>sell</kanji> <kanji>ticket</kanji>? It's a ticket you sell before an event. In other words, an <vocabulary>advance ticket</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>ticket sold in advance</vocabulary>!

前売り券 are often tickets with reduced prices and certain benefits or perks. Note that you'll also see this written as 前売券, without the okurigana, but the reading will stay the same.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are 前, 売る and 券 combined into one awkward word.

examples.en: How much cheaper is a book of tickets?
examples.ja: 回数券だと、どれくらい安くなりますか？

examples.en: An adult set comes with six tickets and it costs 2,050 yen.
examples.ja: 大人の回数券は、6枚つづりで2,050円です。

examples.en: You can also buy a book of train tickets from a ticket outlet.
examples.ja: 電車の回数券は金券ショップでも買えますよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Many <kanji>times</kanji> is how many times you can use this <kanji>number</kanji> of <kanji>ticket</kanji>s. That means there are many tickets, making this a <vocabulary>book of tickets</vocabulary>.

回数券 refers to a book or set of prepaid tickets that are often sold at a discount and can either be physical or digital. They are commonly used for public transportation, like buses or trains, and can also be issued by other businesses that people frequent, such as hot springs and public baths.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I’m so excited to work with a creative person like you.
examples.ja: あなたのような創造力のある人と仕事ができることを、とても楽しみにしています。

examples.en: My little sister is very creative.
examples.ja: 私の妹は、創造力がとても豊かだ。

examples.en: News article writers don't need to be creative.
examples.ja: ニュース記事のライターには、創造力はいらない。

meaning_mnemonic: If 創造 is <kanji>creation</kanji> and you add <kanji>power</kanji> to it, you have <vocabulary>creative power</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well!

examples.en: At any given time, there are many young people who want to work in creative careers.
examples.ja: いつの時代も、創造的な仕事につきたいと思っている若者は多い。

examples.en: Nishino-san is good at coming up with creative ideas.
examples.ja: 西野さんは、創造的なアイデアを考え出すのが得意です。

examples.en: How do you think we can learn to think creatively like her?
examples.ja: 彼女みたいな創造的思考を身に付けるには、どうすればいいと思いますか？

meaning_mnemonic: If 創造 is <kanji>creation</kanji>, then you add 的 to it, which means you have a creational thing, which is quite <vocabulary>creative</vocabulary> wouldn't you say?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: How was your museum date yesterday?
examples.ja: 昨日の博物館デート、どうだった？

examples.en: The other day, my father took me to a museum.
examples.ja: 先日、父に博物館に連れて行ってもらいました。

examples.en: Tomorrow, I'm planning to go to a children's center in the morning and then a museum in the afternoon.
examples.ja: 明日は、朝は児童館に行って、昼からは博物館に行く予定です。

examples.en: I visited the Kyoto National Museum with my mother on Sunday.
examples.ja: 日曜日に母と京都国立博物館に行ってきました。

meaning_mnemonic:
An <kanji>exhibition</kanji> for <kanji>thing</kanji>s is put in a <kanji>public building</kanji> for anyone to see. This place is a <vocabulary>museum</vocabulary>.

Note that 博物館 isn't used for art museums, but for museums that focus on a wide range of other subjects, like natural history, science, history, and technology.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I gambled all my money away.
examples.ja: 博打でお金を全部使い果たしてしまった。

examples.en: What is the difference between an investor and a gambler?
examples.ja: 投資家と博打打ちって、何が違うの？

examples.en: Gambling is illegal in Japan.
examples.ja: 博打を打つことは日本では違法です。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>gambling</kanji> <kanji>hit</kanji> can be multiple things. One type of gambling in Japan that was popular in the day involved betting these awesome wooden block things. You'd gamble by hitting them down on the ground, making a nice thunk sound. Another way to think about it is like blackjack. You want a card? You hit! Either way, it's <vocabulary>gambling</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is weird on this one, but gambling is weird, I guess. はく goes to ばく, maybe because you're playing some gambling <reading>back</reading>gammon. The ち can be <reading>chea</reading>ting, where you cheat at this gambling backgammon. So, you're <reading>back</reading>gammon <reading>chea</reading>ting (ばくち), you big cheater.

examples.en: Every day, I watch the day’s horoscope on the morning TV show and then head to school.
examples.ja: 毎日朝の番組で今日の星占いを見てから学校に行きます。

examples.en: My daughter coldly says that it's stupid to believe in horoscopes, but I can't help looking at them.
examples.ja: 「星占いを信じるとか、バカみたい」ってむすめには冷たく言われるんだけど、ついつい見ちゃうんだよね。

examples.en: Today's horoscope said I should be careful not to get a bump on my head.
examples.ja: 今日の星占いで、頭にたんこぶができないように気をつけた方がいいと出ていたの。

meaning_mnemonic: 占い is "fortune telling." <kanji>Star</kanji> <kanji>fortune</kanji> telling is when you use the stars for fortune telling. That's known as <vocabulary>astrology</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>horoscope</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the words 星 and 占い put together into one. Did you foresee that one coming?

examples.en: Well... I have mixed feelings.
examples.ja: うーん…なんとも微妙な感じですね。

examples.en: I could only come up with doubtful comments, so I ended up saying nothing.
examples.ja: 微妙なコメントしか思いつかなかったので、結局何も言いませんでした。

examples.en: Isn't that picture slightly crooked?
examples.ja: その絵、微妙に曲がってない？

examples.en: My boyfriend gave me a Bird of Paradise plant for my birthday. His taste is not so good, don't you think?
examples.ja: 彼氏から誕生日に極楽鳥花を貰ったんだけど、彼のセンスちょっと微妙だと思わない？

meaning_mnemonic:
Something that's both <kanji>delicate</kanji> and <kanji>peculiar</kanji> is probably <vocabulary>not so good</vocabulary>. It's not terrible, but it's not great either — it could break easily, plus it's kind of strange… It's <vocabulary>not really</vocabulary> good, you know? Think of 微妙 as a sort of euphemism for those delicate and peculiar things you're not really into. 

微妙 can also just mean <vocabulary>delicate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>subtle</vocabulary>, like 微妙な立場 (a delicate position that requires careful handling) or 微妙なニュアンスの違い (a subtle nuance difference that's hard to pinpoint).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Koichi has a strange sticker on his car.
examples.ja: コウイチは、妙なステッカーを車にはっている。

examples.en: Mr. Shimoyama can be strangely argumentative at times.
examples.ja: 下山さんって、妙に理屈屋な時があるよね。

examples.en: Strange. I usually get a call from my mother at this time.
examples.ja: 妙だな。いつもならこの時間には母親から電話がかかってくるんだけど。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Note that 妙 is more often used in writing than conversation.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is actually the same as the kanji you learned. On'yomi all the way, despite being all alone. How <vocabulary>peculiar</vocabulary>!

examples.en: Eels have long been popular as a wonder drug to beat the summer heat.
examples.ja: ウナギは、昔から夏の暑さに負けないための妙薬として人気がありました。

examples.en: Hot wine is also known in Europe as a wonder drug for the common cold.
examples.ja: ホットワインは、ヨーロッパでは、風邪に効く妙薬としても知られています。

examples.en: Is it true that in ancient China, mercury was considered a wonder drug for longevity?
examples.ja: 古代中国では、水銀が不老長生の妙薬とされてきたって本当ですか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>peculiar</kanji> <kanji>drug</kanji> that seems too good to be true? That's what we call a <vocabulary>wonder drug</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>miracle cure</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Where is the women's clothing section?
examples.ja: 婦人服売り場はどこですか？

examples.en: This lady is a gynecologist at an obstetrics and gynecology clinic.
examples.ja: こちらのご婦人は、産婦人科の婦人科医をされているんですよ。

examples.en: I have a lunch tomorrow for the town's women's group.
examples.ja: 明日は町内の婦人会のランチがあるんです。

examples.en: That lady is getting out of hand. What should I do?
examples.ja: あの婦人、俺の手には負えなくなってきたよ。どうしたらいいかな？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>wife</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>lady</vocabulary>, because I guess ladies are wife people? I'm guessing this is pretty sexist somewhere, somehow, but words were made a long time ago so hopefully you can give all those dead people a break.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The married couple both had weak stomachs.
examples.ja: その夫婦は二人共、胃が弱かった。

examples.en: Don't worry, we have a good marriage.
examples.ja: ご心配いただかなくても、夫婦関係は良好ですよ。

examples.en: Mr. and Mrs. Nakama are a couple I admire.
examples.ja: 仲間さん夫婦は、私のあこがれの夫婦です。

examples.en: Oh, honey. Now that we're husband and wife, I hope things go smoother between us.
examples.ja: ねぇ、あなた。これから先、私たち夫婦の間で色々なことがうまくいくといいわね。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>husband</kanji> and <kanji>wife</kanji> combo are a <vocabulary>husband and wife</vocabulary>.

夫婦 is a relatively formal word that refers to a <vocabulary>married couple</vocabulary>, aka <vocabulary>Mr. and Mrs.</vocabulary>
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The housewife made 30,000 yen in stocks.
examples.ja: その主婦は、株で三万円もうけた。

examples.en: Hamada-san checks a blog written by a charismatic housewife at least three times a day.
examples.ja: 浜田さんはカリスマ主婦のブログを一日三回はチェックしている。

examples.en: That housewife has really smooth skin.
examples.ja: あの主婦の肌はものすごくスベスベしている。

examples.en: The ease with which rice and side dishes can be prepared at the touch of a button is quite appreciated by busy housewives.
examples.ja: ボタンひとつでご飯とおかずが完成するお手軽さは、忙しい主婦にとってかなり有難いのである。

examples.en: Is it true that Nara has the highest rate of full-time housewives and the highest rate of piano ownership in Japan?
examples.ja: 奈良って専業主婦率とピアノの保有率が全国1位って本当ですか？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>master</kanji> <kanji>wife</kanji> is the one that takes care of all your stuff for you. She is the <vocabulary>housewife</vocabulary>, a very common profession for married ladies in Japan, though things have been changing little by little. Still, being a housewife means you control the money, which is pretty neat if you ask me.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I feel sorry for that little girl, she's still so young.
examples.ja: あの子、まだ幼いのに、かわいそうだね。

examples.en: There was a little boy who got lost in the hospital.
examples.ja: 病院で、迷子になっている幼い男の子がいました。

examples.en: The older one has a slightly more childish way of thinking.
examples.ja: お兄ちゃんの方が、考え方がちょっと幼いんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji means <kanji>infancy</kanji>. The adjective version describes someone who is <vocabulary>very young</vocabulary>, like little kids in their early childhood or babyhood!

Depending on the context, it can also describe behaviors or ideas that are <vocabulary>childish</vocabulary> or immature, often with a negative connotation.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you were <vocabulary>very young</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>childish</vocabulary> you were sent off to do prayers to ask for forgiveness. One of the things you had to do was sing "<reading>hosanna</reading> (おさな) in the highest."

examples.en: Isn't "Childhood" a book about Tolstoy's childhood memories?
examples.ja: 『幼年時代』って、トルストイの幼年時代の思い出について書かれた本じゃないんですか？

examples.en: At that moment I realized that those happy childhood days would never come back.
examples.ja: その時私は、あの幸せな幼年時代は、もう二度と帰ってはこないんだと実感しました。

examples.en: I always spent my childhood summers at my cousin's place in Kyushu, so the flat stag beetle is a memorable bug for me.
examples.ja: 幼年時代の夏は、いつも九州の従兄弟のところで過ごしたから、ヒラタクワガタは思い出の虫なのだ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You have 時代 as a "period" of time you're talking about. What period? The <kanji>infancy</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji>s. Those years are not just when you're a baby, but when you were growing up, too. That was your <vocabulary>childhood</vocabulary>.

幼年時代 specifically refers to your <vocabulary>early childhood</vocabulary> years. It's a formal word you mostly see in writing with a slightly stiff tone, often appearing in literature, autobiographies, or memoirs looking back on someone's younger years.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Don't worry. The money is kept in the warehouse.
examples.ja: 心配するな。金は、庫の中に入れてある。

examples.en: The door to the granary is securely locked.
examples.ja: 庫の戸には、ちゃんとカギがかかってある。

examples.en: I saw a boy go into the storehouse.
examples.ja: 男の子が庫の中に入っていくのを見たぞ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>storehouse</kanji>, and the vocab is also <vocabulary>storehouse</vocabulary>! Specifically, this usually refers to a traditional Japanese storehouse, which is typically a two story building used to store personal property or merchandise.
reading_mnemonic: What do you put in your <vocabulary>storehouse</vocabulary>? Nothing that nice. Just your totally <reading>cra</reading>shed (くら) car. So sad, it was a nice car, too and now it's all crashed and stored in your warehouse.

examples.en: Do you have a safe in your home?
examples.ja: 家に金庫はありますか？

examples.en: Apparently Mami keeps her bacon in a safe-deposit box.
examples.ja: マミは貸金庫にベーコンをあずけているらしいよ。

examples.en: That bank vault is very sturdy.
examples.ja: あの銀行の金庫はとても頑丈です。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Gold</kanji> <kanji>storage</kanji> is where you put your gold. You want it to be safe, so you put it in <vocabulary>a safe</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>vault</vocabulary>.

金庫 can refer to various types of secure storage. Depending on the context, it can mean a personal safe, a bank vault, or a safety deposit box.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Two BMWs were parked in a row at the garage.
examples.ja: 車庫には、二台のBMWが並列して停められていました。

examples.en: They have a rather unusual apartment complex with a train garage under the apartments.
examples.ja: アパートの下に電車の車庫がある、ちょっと変わった団地があるそうです。

examples.en: When I was backing my parents’ car into the garage I ran it into a pole.
examples.ja: 両親の車を車庫に入れる時に、柱にぶつけてしまいました。

examples.en: A "shako shomei" is a document that certifies a parking space has been secured for a vehicle, and obtaining one is mandated by the Garage Act.
examples.ja: 車庫証明とは自動車の保管場所が確保されていることを証明する書類のことで、車庫法で取得が義務付けられています。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Car</kanji> <kanji>storage</kanji> is where you store your car. It's your <vocabulary>garage</vocabulary>.

車庫 literally means vehicle storage, so it's used for everything from home garages to large depots for public transportation. It carries a bit more of a formal tone than the katakana word ガレージ (garage).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The weather has been improving, hasn't it?
examples.ja: 天気、回復してきたね。

examples.en: This rehabilitation is designed to recover brain function.
examples.ja: このリハビリは、脳の機能を回復するためのものです。

examples.en: The doctor told me that he is not likely to regain consciousness.
examples.ja: 彼が意識を回復することは難しいだろうと医者に言われました。

meaning_mnemonic: 回復 is <kanji>recovery</kanji>. Make it into a verb and you have <vocabulary>to recover</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 回復, but you can also figure it out via the readings of the kanji as well.

examples.en: This ghostly shaped microorganism is "Daphnia magna."
examples.ja: このお化けのような形の微生物は「ミジンコ」です。

examples.en: What time is the the microbiology specialist scheduled to come?
examples.ja: 微生物学の専門家は何時に来る予定ですか。

examples.en: Miso is actually made through the activity of microorganisms.
examples.ja: ミソって実は、微生物の働きによって作られているんですよ。

examples.en: Mr. Kadota had been researching on reading the minds of microbes until two years ago.
examples.ja: 門田さんは二年前まで微生物の心を読み取る研究をしていました。

meaning_mnemonic: You've learned 微 can mean "delicate," but it can also mean <kanji>tiny</kanji>. Combine that with 生物, which you might remember is "living thing," and what do you get? A tiny living thing…? Well, that's a <vocabulary>microorganism</vocabulary>. The tiniest kind of living thing there is.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Isn't that a violation of the Constitution?
examples.ja: それって憲法違反じゃないですか？

examples.en: I'm trying to memorize the full text of the Constitution through rote memorization.
examples.ja: 憲法の全文を丸暗記しています。

examples.en: Freedom of expression is guaranteed by the Constitution.
examples.ja: 表現の自由は憲法で保証されています。

examples.en: I'm busy reviewing the constitutional amendment.
examples.ja: 憲法改正案の見直しで忙しい。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>constitution</kanji> <kanji>law</kanji>s are what makes up the <vocabulary>constitution</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: She is the youngest prime minister in Thailand's constitutional history.
examples.ja: 彼女は、タイの憲政史上最も若い首相です。

examples.en: I am doing a study comparing the constitutional systems of Japan and China.
examples.ja: 私は日本と中国の憲政を比較する研究をしています。

examples.en: Politics conducted by means of a constitution is called "kensei" or "rikken-seiji."
examples.ja: 憲法によって行う政治のことを「憲政」や「立憲政治」といいます。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>constitution</kanji> <kanji>government</kanji> is a <vocabulary>constitutional government</vocabulary>.

憲政 is a formal word that might come up in discussions about democracy or constitutional frameworks, especially in advanced writing.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I got so absorbed into a game, that I was completely losing myself in it.
examples.ja: ゲームに熱中しすぎて、無我夢中の状態になっていた。

examples.en: "Shoot! Fire!" Viet shouted frantically.
examples.ja: 「撃て！撃つんだ！」とビエトは無我夢中でさけんだ。

examples.en: To be honest, I don't remember anything because I was completely absorbed in it.
examples.ja: 正直、無我夢中だったので、何も覚えていません。

examples.en: Working feverishly, he built his house in his twenties and built his tomb in his thirties.
examples.ja: 彼は無我夢中で働き、二十代で家を建てたが、三十代で墓を建てることとなった。

meaning_mnemonic: You already know that 無我 is "selflessness" and 夢中 is "crazy about." So this means something like <vocabulary>total absorption</vocabulary>. You're so into something that you’ve started losing your sense of self. Just like 夢中, this can also describe doing something <vocabulary>frantic</vocabulary>ally, like running away from somebody or something.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I managed to communicate to Japanese people with gestures.
examples.ja: 日本人の人たちと、身振り手振りで何とかコミュニケーションをとることができた。

examples.en: That girl is always exaggerating her gestures and body language.
examples.ja: あの子って、いつも身振り手振りが大げさなんですよね。

examples.en: Viet motioned to his men to hide somewhere.
examples.ja: ビエトは部下に、どこかに隠れるよう身振りで合図した。

examples.en: The man shrugged his shoulders, making a gesture that meant, "So what? I don't know anything about it, okay?"
examples.ja: 男は肩をすくめて「それで？オレは知らねーよ？」という意味の身振りをした。

meaning_mnemonic:
The way your <kanji>body</kanji> <kanji>shake</kanji>s is how you use <vocabulary>body language</vocabulary> or how you <vocabulary>gesture</vocabulary>.

身振り generally refers to gestures in terms of body movements that make communication more expressive or help bridge language barriers. You'll often encounter this together with 手振り (hand gestures) in the phrase 身振り手振り.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this is the kun'yomis for 身 and 振る put together, where the 振り gets rendaku'd to ぶり.

examples.en: Please add the furigana for your name in katakana.
examples.ja: 名前にはカタカナで振り仮名をつけてください。

examples.en: We don't use furigana since Wanikani is a site to study kanji.
examples.ja: ワニカニは漢字を勉強するサイトなので、振り仮名は使いません。

examples.en: I found a job where I add small kana characters to kanji.
examples.ja: 漢字に振り仮名を振る仕事を見つけました。

meaning_mnemonic: 振る is "to shake." 仮名 is kana. This word refers to <vocabulary>furigana</vocabulary>, which is the little kana that's put next to kanji for the people who don't use WaniKani and can't read anything. As to why it's called "shake kana"? I have no clue. Just imagine putting little kana next to kanji and watching them shake around, though, and you should be good to go.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are 振る and 仮名 put together into one. If you know those words, you won't need no furigana to help you with this word.

examples.en: I found a job as an interviewer who conducts interviews during the interview examination process with exam candidates.
examples.ja: 面接試験で受験生を面接する面接官の仕事を見つけました。

examples.en: I checked out the homepage of the company that I'm gonna have a job interview with a day after tomorrow, and found out it's definitely a yakuza company.
examples.ja: 明後日面接する会社のホームページをのぞいたら、バリバリのヤクザ会社だった。

examples.en: It looks like the final interview will be a one-on-one interview with the president of this company. I hope I can get there.
examples.ja: 最終面接は社長面接で、この企業の社長と一対一で面接するみたいです。そこまでたどり着けるといいんだけど。

meaning_mnemonic:
面接 is an <kanji>interview</kanji>. Make that into a verb and you have to <vocabulary>interview with</vocabulary>.

Remember that 面接 is an interview for a job or admission to a school, not an interview for a magazine or a TV show. インタビューする is the more appropriate word for a media interview.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know the word 面接 as well.

examples.en: Don’t move. Hold still or you’ll be shot!
examples.ja: 動くな。じっとしていないと、撃つぞ！

examples.en: No, there's no need to shoot that bear.
examples.ja: いや、あのクマを撃つ必要はないだろ。

examples.en: In the real battle, you have to win even by shooting the enemy from the rear.
examples.ja: 実戦では、敵を後ろから撃ってでも勝たなければいけない。

examples.en: I know it sounds paradoxical, but I shot you to protect you.
examples.ja: 逆説めくが、私はお前を守るために撃ったんだ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>to attack</kanji>, but 撃つ means <vocabulary>to shoot</vocabulary>.

This can mean <vocabulary>to fire</vocabulary> a weapon such as a gun or to shoot a projectile, like an arrow. It can also mean to shoot a person or animal.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

What are you going <vocabulary>to shoot</vocabulary> at? <reading>U</reading>ni (う)! Why? Because this area is overrun with those black, spiky sea urchins. You need to cull them by shooting them down.

examples.en: The server is under cyber attack.
examples.ja: サーバーがサイバー攻撃を受けている。

examples.en: The enemy will probably attack the megacities first.
examples.ja: 敵はまず巨大都市を攻撃してくるだろう。

examples.en: You are such a coward to make a surprise attack from the back.
examples.ja: 後ろから攻撃を仕掛けてくるなんて、ひきょうだぞ！

examples.en: It was the sexiest missile attack I've ever seen.
examples.ja: 今まで見た中で一番セクシーなミサイル攻撃だったよ。

examples.en: Yesterday, an armed attack was launched.
examples.ja: 昨日、武力攻撃が開始された。

meaning_mnemonic:
With <kanji>aggression</kanji> you <kanji>attack</kanji> the enemy. This is an <vocabulary>attack</vocabulary>.

攻撃 usually refers to <vocabulary>attacking</vocabulary> someone or something with the intent of causing direct harm or damage, either physically or verbally. You'll hear it used in the context of war, games, arguments, or even things like media criticism or cyberattacks.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Tomorrow, we will attack the enemy's castle.
examples.ja: 明日、敵の城を攻めるぞ。

examples.en: Thank you for your question. You’re tackling a rather difficult point.
examples.ja: ご質問ありがとうございます。中々難しいところを攻めてきますね。

examples.en: That pitcher often assaults batters with curve balls.
examples.ja: そのピッチャーはバッターを変化球で攻めることが多い。

examples.en: Setting logic aside, I just kept pushing and pushing relentlessly.
examples.ja: 理屈は抜きにして、とりあえず攻めて攻めて攻めまくりました。

meaning_mnemonic:
You don't say "to aggression." When you do aggression on someone, you're probably doing something to hurt them in some way. This is an attack, making this word <vocabulary>to attack</vocabulary>.

攻める means to attack or advance on an enemy in battle, but it can also apply to making a strong or proactive move in competitions like sports, business, or games. It can also be used to describe taking bold actions, like moving ahead with a risky plan.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>To attack</vocabulary> someone, use a <reading>ce</reading>lery (せ) stick. Celery is not a deadly weapon but most people hate it, so it's perfect to casually attack someone, especially those who hate celery.

examples.en: What is your major?
examples.ja: 専攻は何ですか？

examples.en: I'm majoring in fine arts.
examples.ja: 私はファインアートを専攻しています。

examples.en: She is an anthropology student of this university.
examples.ja: 彼女はうちの大学の、人類学専攻の学生なんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>specialty</kanji>, which you focus on with <kanji>aggression</kanji>, is your <vocabulary>major</vocabulary> in college (your <vocabulary>college major</vocabulary>). Study hard, young grasshopper.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: At the same time, the Soviet Union launched a counter-offensive.
examples.ja: これと同時に、ソ連が反攻を開始しました。

examples.en: In 1944, the Allied forces shifted to a counteroffensive.
examples.ja: 1944年に連合軍は反攻に転じました。

examples.en: Of course, our army is preparing for a counter-attack. However, we are not yet ready and are in a situation in which we cannot launch a counter-attack.
examples.ja: もちろん我が軍は、反攻を準備している。しかし、まだ準備が整っておらず、反攻を行うことができない状況にあるのだ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Anti</kanji> <kanji>aggression</kanji> is when you receive some aggression, then respond to it with anti aggression, aka your <vocabulary>counterattack</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I just saw a mitten crab on the beach!
examples.ja: さっき、浜でモクズガニを見ました！

examples.en: The beach winds felt nice.
examples.ja: 浜風が気持ちよかった。

examples.en: What, were you also on the beach that day, Hama-san?
examples.ja: え、浜さんもこの日、浜にいたんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It's worth mentioning that a more common way to say beach is ビーチ, and many people actually say 海 even though this literally means "sea."
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Could you give me a ride to Yokohama please?
examples.ja: 横浜まで乗せてもらえませんか？

examples.en: I once lived in Yokohama for about three months.
examples.ja: 私は三ヶ月ほど横浜に住んでいたことがあります。

examples.en: Is it true that people born and raised in Yokohama are called “Hamakko”?
examples.ja: 横浜生まれ、横浜育ちの人のことを「浜っ子」って言うって本当ですか？

meaning_mnemonic: It's the <kanji>side</kanji> of the <kanji>beach</kanji>! Well, wait, what is it? This will make better sense when you look at the reading for the word, since it's a place: <vocabulary>Yokohama</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 横 and 浜 put together into one nice word, <reading>よこはま</reading>.

examples.en: But apparently only those with pure hearts can see it.
examples.ja: でも、心の清い人にしか見えないんだって。

examples.en: My motto is "Purity, Honesty, Beauty."
examples.ja: 「清く正しく美しく」が私のモットーです。

examples.en: You know how they say, "If the water is clear, the fish won't live there"?
examples.ja: 「水清ければ魚住まず」って言うでしょ？

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>pure</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>pure</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "In order to stay <vocabulary>pure</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>clean</vocabulary>, you shouldn't ever do anything dirty or bad. That is the <reading>key, yo</reading> (きよ)."

examples.en: We're supposed to keep our kitchens clean, right?
examples.ja: キッチンは清潔にしておくものでしょ？

examples.en: The restaurant was clean and well kept, and the food was delicious.
examples.ja: おそうじの行き届いた清潔なお店で、ご飯も美味しかったです。

examples.en: That clinic is very clean.
examples.ja: あそこのクリニックはとても清潔です。

examples.en: My type is a guy who is actually clean but looks dirty and sketchy.
examples.ja: 実際には清潔だけど、見た目は汚らしくてちょっと影がある男の人がタイプです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Something so <kanji>pure</kanji> it's <kanji>pure</kanji> twice. It must be really <vocabulary>clean</vocabulary>! <vocabulary>Cleanliness</vocabulary> is next to pure...liness, after all. I'm sure that's how the saying goes.

清潔 is a relatively formal word that refers to <vocabulary>sanitary</vocabulary> conditions in personal hygiene, public health, or medical settings. It can refer to both physically clean places and hygienic practices. In literature, 清潔 can also describe a person as morally pure.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Well, that was a graceful decision.
examples.ja: いやー、あれは潔い判断でしたね。

examples.en: It seems my dad liked your gracious attitude.
examples.ja: お父さん、君の潔い態度が気に入ったみたい。

examples.en: I apologized graciously for missing the deadline and was forgiven pretty easily.
examples.ja: 締切に間に合わなかったことを潔く謝ったら、あっさり許してもらえました。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. The kanji means <kanji>pure</kanji>, but this is an adjective that often describes behavior or character, so it means <vocabulary>honorable</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>dignified</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>gracious</vocabulary>.

How does that work? I guess if you can stay pure despite a tough situation, you must be pretty honorable and dignified. You're the type who can make a gracious apology (潔い謝り), have a dignified manner (潔い態度), or even die honorably (潔く死ぬ).

潔い is about being strong and doing the right thing without hesitation, especially when it's hard. For example, when someone admits their mistake honestly or handles a tough situation with courage, you can say they're 潔い. It's a way to praise someone for being straightforward and admirable in difficult times.
reading_mnemonic: Oh man, the reading for this is... like... crazy. First part can be something like <reading>i</reading>t's <reading>soggy</reading> (いさぎ)... then the second part is like the word 良い (good). So, you can think of a <vocabulary>honorable</vocabulary>person eating soggy cereal. They're so gracious that it doesn't matter to them how soggy it is. In fact, they accept it with dignity! They keep saying "it's soggy... 良い!" over and over again while eating the terribly soggy food.

examples.en: Don't touch me with your dirty hands!
examples.ja: 不潔な手で私をさわらないでください！

examples.en: I decided to break up with him when I saw his filthy room.
examples.ja: 不潔な部屋を見て、別れを決意した。

examples.en: There is nothing more filthy than a white coat worn by a doctor.
examples.ja: 医者が着る白衣ほど不潔なものはありません。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Not</kanji> <kanji>clean</kanji> things are <vocabulary>filthy</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>dirty</vocabulary>. Ewughh.

不潔 is a relatively formal word that refers to <vocabulary>unsanitary</vocabulary> conditions in personal hygiene, public health, or medical settings. It can refer to both dirty environments and poor hygiene practices. In literature, 不潔 can also describe something as morally dirty to evoke disgust, though this use is somewhat old-fashioned.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: He talks to himself very often, doesn't he?
examples.ja: アイツは本当に独り言が多いよな。

examples.en: Kaoru was muttering to herself.
examples.ja: カオルはブツブツ独り言をつぶやいていた。

examples.en: My mother blushed when neighbors heard her talking to herself.
examples.ja: 母は、独り言を言ってるのを近所の人に聞かれて赤面した。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 独り means "alone"? Well, if someone is alone and <kanji>say</kanji>ing something aloud, it constitutes <vocabulary>talking to oneself</vocabulary>.

独り言 means talking or muttering to yourself aloud, whether alone or in public. It can also refer to the words themselves — the things you say as you talk to yourself.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 独り is just the reading for 独り. The reading for 言 is an exception, though. It's ごと, which comes from こと. Just think that as you're talking to yourself you're telling yourself over and over to <reading>go to</reading> hell. You're mean to yourself, and you're also insane, which is why you keep saying that out loud to nobody but you.

examples.en: Why do you do this when it results in so little profit?
examples.ja: どうしてこんな利益がほとんど出ないことをするんですか？

examples.en: How much profit does Tofugu make in a day?
examples.ja: トーフグの一日の利益はどのぐらいですか？

examples.en: He is a politician who can act in the best interest of society.
examples.ja: 彼は社会の利益を考えて行動できる政治家です。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Profit</kanji> and <kanji>benefit</kanji> literally means <vocabulary>profit</vocabulary>and <vocabulary>benefit</vocabulary>. Just like the English word "profit," it is often used to refer to financial gain, but can also be used for benefits that are non-financial as well.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Thank you for your beneficial advice.
examples.ja: 有益なアドバイス、有難うございます。

examples.en: I think that if you are going to do business, it must be a beneficial service to society, otherwise it is meaningless.
examples.ja: ビジネスをするなら、社会にとって有益なサービスでないと、意味がないと思うんです。

examples.en: Thank you very much for your very useful information.
examples.ja: 非常に有益な情報を提供していただき、有り難うございます。

meaning_mnemonic:
To <kanji>have</kanji> <kanji>benefit</kanji> is to be <vocabulary>beneficial</vocabulary>.

有益 is a more formal word than 役に立つ (useful). It's often used for things like 有益なアドバイス (beneficial advice) or 有益な情報 (useful information).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm working for a nonprofit foundation.
examples.ja: 私は公益法人で働いています。

examples.en: I'm trying to invest in stocks from a public benefit perspective.
examples.ja: 私は公益の観点で投資をするようにしています。

examples.en: I thought that Tofugu was a public benefit corporation that has been doing public service for a long time.
examples.ja: トーフグのこと、ずっと公益事業をしている公益法人だと思っていました。

examples.en: That decision could harm the public interest.
examples.ja: その決定は公益を害する可能性があります。

examples.en: A company that praises actions contrary to the public interest — isn't that messed up?
examples.ja: 公益に反する行動が評価される会社って、どうかしてると思いませんか？

meaning_mnemonic:
Something for <kanji>public</kanji> <kanji>benefit</kanji> is for <vocabulary>public benefit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>public interest</vocabulary>.

公益 is a formal word used to describe activities or organizations that have a positive impact on society or the general public.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It's the diplomat's job to protect national interests, right?
examples.ja: 国益を守るのが外交官の仕事でしょ？

examples.en: I want to be a politician who can act in the national interest even if everyone hates me.
examples.ja: みんなに嫌われても、国益を考えて行動できる政治家になりたいと思っています。

examples.en: Don't you think we should put global interests before national interests and moreover universal interests before global interests?
examples.ja: 国益より地球益、さらには地球益より宇宙益を優先させるべきだと思いませんか？

examples.en: Japanese people's poor English could damage national interests in the future.
examples.ja: 日本人の英会話力不足によって、将来国益が損なわれる可能性がある。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>country</kanji> will <kanji>benefit</kanji> from these actions. It will create <vocabulary>national benefit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>national interests</vocabulary>.

国益 is a word that is often found in formal political, diplomatic, and economic writing.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: We are considering moving our office to Ginza.
examples.ja: 銀座に事務所を移すことを検討しています。

examples.en: It's hard to put ideas into action, isn't it?
examples.ja: アイディアを実行に移すのが難しいんですよね。

examples.en: I feel that successful people are quick to take action on everything.
examples.ja: 成功者は、何でも行動に移すのが速い気がします。

examples.en: I transferred the strawberries to the blender.
examples.ja: 私は苺をミキサーに移しました。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shift</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to shift</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: All that dubstep (<reading>うつ</reading>うつうつうつうつ) playing downstairs is causing all of your glassware <vocabulary>to shift</vocabulary> off the shelf and onto the floor. Damn that dubstep. うつうつうつうつうつ♪

examples.en: Do you think Japan will accept more immigrants in the future?
examples.ja: 今後、日本は移民の受け入れを増やすと思いますか？

examples.en: I heard that Hoshi-san's husband immigrated to the U.S. from France.
examples.ja: 星さんの夫は、フランスからアメリカに移民してきたそうです。

examples.en: I am a Canadian Government Certified Immigration Consultant.
examples.ja: 私はカナダ政府公認移民コンサルタントです。

examples.en: I confessed my secret that I'm an illegal immigrant to her.
examples.ja: 私は、自分が不法移民であるという秘密を彼女に告白した。

meaning_mnemonic: When you're <kanji>shift</kanji>ing <kanji>peoples</kanji>, you're causing either <vocabulary>immigration</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>emigration</vocabulary>, which leads to… <vocabulary>immigrant</vocabulary>s, or <vocabulary>emigrant</vocabulary>s.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I don't have any plans to emigrate to Japan for now.
examples.ja: 今のところ、日本への移住の予定は無いです。

examples.en: It's more difficult to migrate from Japan to America than it is from America to Japan.
examples.ja: 日本からアメリカへ移住するのは、アメリカから日本へ移住するよりも難しい。

examples.en: That depends on whether or not you will move to this country.
examples.ja: それはあなたがこの国に移住して来るか来ないかによります。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>shift</kanji> the place you <kanji>dwell</kanji>, that's called <vocabulary>migration</vocabulary>.

移住 is a relatively formal word for the act of moving to a new place to live, often in a long-term or permanent sense. This word can mean moving to a new town or city, or it can refer to <vocabulary>immigration</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>emigration</vocabulary> to a different country.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That singer is a good singer, but they're not as good as Beyoncé.
examples.ja: あの歌手、歌は上手いけど、ビヨンセ程ではないよね。

examples.en: It wasn't as expensive as I expected, so I ended up clicking to place the order right away.
examples.ja: 思った程高くなかったので、思わずポチってしまいました。

examples.en: The more I heard about it, the scarier it got.
examples.ja: 聞けば聞く程、こわくなってきました。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

You'll see 程 used in all kinds of ways to express the <vocabulary>extent</vocabulary> or degree of something, like 思った程じゃない (not as much as I expected), 言葉で表せない程すごい (so amazing it can't be expressed in words), or 30分程歩く (to walk for about thirty minutes). Just keep in mind this word is often written in kana.
reading_mnemonic: You'll remember this kanji to the <vocabulary>extent</vocabulary> that you study it. If you study it like <reading>Hodo</reading>r (ほど) would study it, you won't learn it at all. You would only be able to say "hodor, hodor," over and over again, which isn't helpful at all.

examples.en: If you get scared by just this amount of money, you wouldn't be able to do anything.
examples.ja: この程度の金額でビビってたらなんにもできないよ。

examples.en: To what extent do you know about the rumors?
examples.ja: そのウワサについて、どの程度ご存知ですか？

examples.en: Just not to the point of seriously offending him, but in moderation!
examples.ja: 本気で怒らせない程度に、ほどほどにね！

examples.en: He is actually 35 years old, but has no more intelligence than a three year old kid.
examples.ja: 彼は実際は35歳だが、3歳児と同程度の知能水準しかない。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>extent</kanji>'s <kanji>degree</kanji> is the <vocabulary>degree</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>extent</vocabulary> you're willing to take something.

程度 can also indicate an approximate <vocabulary>level</vocabulary>, like 一時間程度 (for about an hour) or この程度 (to this extent). To get a sense of the different uses, check out the context section.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I always try to enjoy the process of creating my own work.
examples.ja: 私はいつも自分の作品を作り上げていく過程を楽しむようにしています。

examples.en: My child is recording the growth process of insects for his research project during summer vacation.
examples.ja: うちの子は夏休みの自由研究で、昆虫の成長過程を記録しています。

examples.en: It was inevitable that the project failed, but if you don't think about the process of why it happened and be able to explain it, you won't be able to use the failure to your advantage the next time.
examples.ja: プロジェクトが失敗したことは仕方のないことですが、どうしてそうなったかの過程を考え、説明できるようにしないと、失敗を次に活かせませんよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Surpass</kanji> the <kanji>extent</kanji>... okay, what does that even mean? You figure out the extent of your abilities, and then you surpass them to get better. You have to do this over and over again in order to keep getting better. It's a <vocabulary>process</vocabulary> that must be accomplished if you ever hope to get better than you are now.
