過程 is often used to describe ongoing progress, like 生産過程 (production process), but it can also be used to talk about how things develop. For example, you might reflect on the 過程 that led to your current job, or explain the steps a team follows to finish a project.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What kind of travel itinerary do you have in mind?
examples.ja: 旅行の日程って、どんな感じで考えてる？

examples.en: I'll let you know the schedule for the on-the-job training as soon as it's decided.
examples.ja: 職場研修の日程は、決まり次第連絡しますね。

examples.en: Now, in accordance with the schedule of the proceedings, we will now move on to the discussion items.
examples.ja: では、議事日程に従い、審議案件に移ります。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>day</kanji>'s <kanji>extent</kanji> is that we're going to do this, this, and this. That is our <vocabulary>schedule</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>itinerary</vocabulary>, so stick to it.

日程 is a relatively formal word used to talk about the schedule for a specific event, meeting, or activity.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My husband is really immature.
examples.ja: うちの夫、本当に幼稚なんだよね。

examples.en: I don't mean to contradict you, but don't you think you are the one who has childish ideas?
examples.ja: お言葉を返すようですが、幼稚な考えを持っているのは、ご自身の方じゃないですか？

examples.en: My child is now attending the kindergarten section of a Japanese language school on Saturday mornings.
examples.ja: うちの子は今、土曜日の朝にある日本語学校の幼稚部に通っています。

examples.en: Why do so many Japanese girls speak like children?
examples.ja: どうして幼稚な喋り方をする日本人女性が多いのですか？

meaning_mnemonic:
He who is both in his <kanji>infancy</kanji> and <kanji>immature</kanji> is probably <vocabulary>childish</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>immature</vocabulary>.

When used as an adjective, 幼稚 describes negative immaturity in someone's behavior, remarks, or ideas. However, in compounds like 幼稚園 (kindergarten), it simply refers to the early childhood stage without any negative tone.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My father is mentally ill and goes to a mental hospital.
examples.ja: 私の父は、精神を病んで精神病院に通っています。

examples.en: If you focus your mind and study hard, you'll be fluent in Japanese in a month.
examples.ja: 精神を集中して勉強すれば、一ヶ月で日本語がペラペラになるよ。

examples.en: Our school values the spirit of freedom and independence, so there are no school rules.
examples.ja: うちの学校は自由と独立の精神を重んじているので、校則がありません。

meaning_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>spirit</kanji> <kanji>spirit</kanji> is… your <vocabulary>spirit</vocabulary>. This word is for the human <vocabulary>mind</vocabulary> and can refer to your mental state, thinking, attitude, mindset, or even willpower. 

Depending on the context, 精神 can also mean "spirit" as in the essence or core principle of something, like 独立の精神 (the spirit of independence).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It's said that the precision of that country’s missiles are still low.
examples.ja: あの国のミサイルの精度はまだ低いと言われている。

examples.en: Eh, isn't your impersonation too accurate?
examples.ja: え、モノマネの精度、高すぎない？

examples.en: I'd like to improve the accuracy of my sketches, how do you think I can improve the accuracy?
examples.ja: デッサンの精度を高めたいんですが、どうすれば精度が上がると思いますか？

meaning_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>spirit</kanji>'s <kanji>degree</kanji> of focus is what helps you to hone your <vocabulary>precision</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>accuracy</vocabulary>, for some reason. Just imagine yourself throwing a ball. You miss the target. Hmm, okay... time to power up like on Dragonball. Up that spirit energy. Turn the degrees up on it. Boom. Awesome. Now throw again. Hit! You hit it! What great precision you have gained by honing your spirit!

精度 is a relatively formal word, often used to talk about the precision or accuracy of something in technical or analytical contexts.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Please teach me about how to break up with my lover.
examples.ja: 恋人との関係を絶つ方法を教えてください。

examples.en: In order to secure a responsible position in the international community, it is not desirable for us to break off diplomatic relations with other countries.
examples.ja: 国際社会で責任ある立場を得るには、こちら側から他国との国交を絶ち断交するのは望ましくありません。

examples.en: Three years ago, when just the two of us went out drinking, my best friend suddenly got up and just walked out of the bar, leaving his smartphone and wallet behind. And then I never heard from him ever again.
examples.ja: 三年前、サシ飲みの途中にさ、親友がスマホも財布も置いたまま、突然ふらりと店を出たんだよね。で、そのまま消息を絶っちゃったの。

examples.en: Some people try to end their own lives because they feel they are of no use to anyone, but just by registering with the bone marrow bank and donating blood every day, you can help a lot of people.
examples.ja: 自分は誰の役にも立たないからといって自ら命を絶とうとする人もいますが、骨髄バンクに登録して、毎日献血するだけでも、たくさんの人の役に立てるんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>extinction</kanji> or <kanji>die out</kanji>, but the verb version here means <vocabulary>to break off contact</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to sever</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to end</vocabulary>. Just think about how when you’re breaking off contact with somebody, you’re essentially making them go extinct or die out from your life completely. It’s such a complete severance, they basically stop existing to you.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

In terms of things you need <vocabulary>to sever</vocabulary>, <reading>ta</reading>cos (た) are #1 on your list. No more tacos for you, going to cut those off from my diet.

examples.en: Don't worry mom. I can go to the candy store by myself.
examples.ja: お母さん、心配しなくていいよ。あのお菓子屋さんなら僕、一人でも行けるよ。

examples.en: I bought this canelé from my favorite local pastry shop.
examples.ja: 大好きな地元のお菓子屋さんで買ってきたカヌレです。

examples.en: Is there a pastry shop in this market that carries Runeberg tarts?
examples.ja: このマーケットに、ルーネベリタルトを置いているお菓子屋さんはありますか？

examples.en: Among the candy shops, there are several types, such as Japanese sweet stores and Western sweet stores.
examples.ja: お菓子屋さんにも和菓子屋さんや洋菓子屋さんなど、いくつかの種類があるんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: お菓子 is "candy," right? Add <kanji>store</kanji> onto that and you have a <vocabulary>candy store</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. It will help to know the word お菓子 as well.

examples.en: Please listen closely to the voice of the general public.
examples.ja: もっと大衆の声に耳をかたむけてください。

examples.en: Due to the massive earthquake, the crowds were panicked.
examples.ja: 巨大地震で大衆はパニックにおちいった。

examples.en: It depends on how the masses feel.
examples.ja: 大衆の感じ方次第です。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>populous</kanji> place sounds like a place with a lot of people but it's more like a big part of the populace. It's most of the populace, sure, making it the <vocabulary>general public</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What is the percentage of female members in the House of Representatives in Japan?
examples.ja: 日本の衆議院における女性議員の割合はどれぐらいですか？

examples.en: Yesterday, the draft budget for the tax increase passed in the Lower House.
examples.ja: 昨日、増税の予算案が衆議院を通過してしまいました。

examples.en: There are rumors that that councilor is considering resigning from the House of Councilors and becoming a member of the House of Representatives.
examples.ja: あの議員は参議院を辞めて、衆議院議員になることを検討しているというウワサもあります。

examples.en: It was revealed that a member of the House of Representatives chartered a boat at government expense.
examples.ja: ある衆議院議員が公費でボートを借りたことが明らかになりました。

meaning_mnemonic: It's the <kanji>institution</kanji> that does <kanji>deliberation</kanji> on behalf of the <kanji>populace</kanji>. They represent the people. They are the <vocabulary>house of representatives</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My oldest son made a piggy bank at school.
examples.ja: 長男が学校で貯金箱を作ってきました。

examples.en: The 500-yen coin piggy bank that I started when I was ten years old is finally full!
examples.ja: 10才の時に始めた500円玉貯金箱が、ついにいっぱいになりました！

examples.en: Koichi's piggy bank is much bigger than mine, to the point where you can't even compare them.
examples.ja: コウイチの貯金箱は、私の貯金箱とは比較にならない程大きい。

examples.en: My brother confessed that he had stolen my piggy bank ten years ago.
examples.ja: 兄は、十年前に私の貯金箱を盗んだ事を白状しました。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 貯金 means "savings"? Well, a <kanji>box</kanji> you put said savings in is a <vocabulary>savings box</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>piggy bank</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This restaurant is relatively cheap given it's in Ginza.
examples.ja: この店は、銀座にしては比較的安いんだよ。

examples.en: This book uses comparatively difficult words despite being juvenile literature.
examples.ja: この本は、児童文学にしては比較的難しい言葉を使っているね。

examples.en: As a matter of fact, Japan is one of the G7 countries with relatively low taxes.
examples.ja: 実は日本って、G７の中では税金が比較的安い方なんです。

meaning_mnemonic: 比較 is a comparison. Add 的 to it and you have <vocabulary> comparatively</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know the word 比較.

examples.en: Isn't that shirt on backwards?
examples.ja: そのシャツ、前と後ろが逆じゃない？

examples.en: Koichi has the complete opposite personality of his older brother, doesn't he?
examples.ja: コウイチって、お兄さんとは真逆な性格をしてるよね。

examples.en: I wanted to loosen the screw, but I ended up turning it in the opposite way and tightened it instead.
examples.ja: ネジをゆるめたかったのに、逆に回して締めつけてしまっていた。

examples.en: Are there more and more people driving on the wrong side of the road recently? There was a truck driving the wrong way on the highway just now!
examples.ja: 最近、道路を逆に走る人、増えてない？さっきも高速道路を逆走しているトラックがいたよ！

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Keep in mind that 逆 often implies something is the <vocabulary>reverse</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>opposite</vocabulary> of what it should be. For example, you use 逆 when you're going in the opposite direction of your destination or wearing your shirt backwards.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji as well. Lucky! <kanji>Reverse</kanji> face time!

examples.en: Isn't that counterproductive?
examples.ja: それ、逆効果じゃない？

examples.en: I wanted to cheer him up, but it had the opposite effect.
examples.ja: 励ますつもりが、逆効果になってしまった。

examples.en: I expected to capture his heart by filling his stomach, but it backfired.
examples.ja: 胃ぶくろを満たしてハートをつかむはずが、逆効果だった。

meaning_mnemonic: 効果 means "effect," so the <kanji>opposite</kanji> of said effect is the <vocabulary>opposite effect</vocabulary>. Or in other terms, something <vocabulary>counterproductive</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as  well. Will help to know 効果 as well.

examples.en: You're going against your parents?
examples.ja: お前、親に逆らうつもりか？

examples.en: After all, no one can go against the current of the times.
examples.ja: やっぱり、誰も時代の流れに逆らうことはできないんだよ。

examples.en: Fugu was moved by Salmon who was swimming upstream against the river's flow.
examples.ja: フグは流れに逆らって川を上って行くサーモンに感動を覚えた。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>opposite</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to go against</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to oppose</vocabulary>.

逆らう refers to resisting natural or social forces, like 逆らって進む (to go against the tide), or to opposing specific people, like 親に逆らう (to defy one's parents). It means actively resisting something, whether it's a flow, a trend, or authority, highlighting a conscious choice to take a different path.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Just like when you play <reading>soccer</reading> (さか). You never play right, causing you <vocabulary>to go against</vocabulary> all things you're supposed to do and shoot goals into your own goalie's net.

examples.en: That legislator often uses paradoxical logic.
examples.ja: あの議員は、逆説の論理をよく使います。

examples.en: This manga is a paradoxical story that makes us think about life through the battles between those who have become immortal.
examples.ja: このマンガは、不死の存在となった者同士の戦いを通じて命について考える、逆説的な物語です。

examples.en: Excellent people want to go to places where they can grow, so companies that aim "high" have a lot of talented people. Paradoxically, companies that do not attract good people have low goals.
examples.ja: 優秀な人は成長できる場に行きたがるんで、「高い目標」を目指している企業には、良い人材が多いんです。逆説的に言えば、良い人が集まらない企業は、目標が低いんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: It is <kanji>reverse</kanji> to the <kanji>theory</kanji>! What is going on? Things aren't right. There must be some kind of <vocabulary>paradox</vocabulary> going on, where all theories are reversed! D:
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Those who think they can get by if they just smile and laugh are very mistaken.
examples.ja: ニコニコ笑っておけば何とかなるでしょって思ってる人は大間違いですよ。

examples.en: The original big mistake was that we tried to record outdoors.
examples.ja: そもそも、野外で録音しようとしたのが大間違いだった。

examples.en: If you think this is the end of summer, you are mistaken! The real summer is yet to come.
examples.ja: これで夏が終わったと思ったら大間違いだよ！本当の夏は、まだまだこれからなんだから。

examples.en: I asked her to go out with me, but it was a big mistake.
examples.ja: 彼女をデートに誘ったが、それは大間違いだった。

meaning_mnemonic:
A 間違い is a mistake. A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>mistake</kanji> is a <vocabulary>big mistake</vocabulary>.

大間違い is less about factual errors and more about someone being way off in their assumptions or expectations. It suggests things didn't go according to plan — like you assumed a smile would fix everything or expected a date to go well, only for things to turn out completely wrong.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 大 and 間違い put together into one not so mistaken word.

examples.en: Is there a post office in this area?
examples.ja: この辺に郵便局はありますか？

examples.en: Could you get ten stamps at the post office for me?
examples.ja: 郵便局で切手を十枚買ってきてくれない？

examples.en: My uncle is the postmaster of that post office.
examples.ja: 私のおじは、あの郵便局の郵便局長なんです。

examples.en: I made a complaint about the post office’s service.
examples.ja: 郵便局のサービスに対して苦情を言いました。

meaning_mnemonic: With 郵便 being <kanji>mail</kanji> and 局 being bureau, we have the "mail bureau." They're more often known as the <vocabulary>post office</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know the word 郵便 as well.

examples.en: What is your postal code number?
examples.ja: 郵便番号は何番ですか？

examples.en: I haven’t memorized my new postal code yet.
examples.ja: まだ新しい郵便番号を覚えていません。

examples.en: How many digits are there in an American zip code?
examples.ja: アメリカの郵便番号は何ケタあるんですか？

examples.en: Apparently I wrote the wrong post number and the delivery seems to have been delayed.
examples.ja: 郵便番号を間違えて書いてしまっていたようで、配達がおくれているみたいです。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that a 郵便 is the <kanji>mail</kanji> and that a 番号 is a <kanji>number</kanji>. So a "mail number," what is that? Usually refers to your <vocabulary>post number</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>postal code</vocabulary>. It is also often referred to with a symbol, which is 〒, so look out for that.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: How could this book fit in my small mailbox?
examples.ja: どうやって私の小さな郵便箱にこの本が入ったんだろう。

examples.en: There was one mailbox mounted next to the nameplate in front of my house.
examples.ja: 僕の家の前の表札の横には、郵便箱が一つ取り付けてあった。

examples.en: This mailbox has a camera in it!
examples.ja: この郵便箱、カメラがついてるよ！

examples.en: Since so many love letters are delivered to Koichi, we use a gigantic tanker as a mailbox instead.
examples.ja: コウイチあてのラブレターがあまりにもたくさん届くので、巨大なタンカーを郵便箱の代わりに使っています。

meaning_mnemonic:
郵便 is the "mail." A <kanji>box</kanji> that's used with said mail is a <vocabulary>postbox</vocabulary>.

郵便箱 used to refer specifically to a public <vocabulary>collection box</vocabulary> where you drop off your mail to be sent. But now, some people use it for their home <vocabulary>mailboxes</vocabulary> too! Don't worry — you can usually tell which is which from context.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Did you record Koichi's speech?
examples.ja: コウイチのスピーチ、録音した？

examples.en: We have a Gundam party today, so let's postpone the podcast recording to Monday.
examples.ja: 今日はガンダムパーティーがあるので、ポッドキャストの録音は月曜日にしましょう。

examples.en: Sorry! I thought I clicked the record button, but it didn't record!
examples.ja: ごめん！録音ボタンをクリックしたつもりだったのに、録音できてなかった！

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>record</kanji> of <kanji>sound</kanji> is a <vocabulary>sound recording</vocabulary> of some kind. Might be minidisk, might be CD, might be digital. Whatever it is, it's still the record of sound.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: How many subscribers does Tofugu's YouTube channel have?
examples.ja: TofuguのYouTubeチャンネルの登録者って何人くらいですか？

examples.en: I plan to register for Japanese classes again next semester.
examples.ja: 来学期も日本語のクラスに登録するつもりです。

examples.en: Have you completed your resident registration already?
examples.ja: 住民登録はもうお済みですか？

examples.en: This is Yuka Miyake. I’ve changed my phone, so could you register my new number and email address in your address book, please? Thank you.
examples.ja: 三宅結花です。携帯電話を変えたので、新しい電話番号とメールアドレスの登録をお願いします。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Climb</kanji> up and <kanji>record</kanji> your information here. This is <vocabulary>registration</vocabulary>. It's work to get yourself registered (from the climbing) and even if you get your name recorded on there, you may not get in. So record your information, wait, and hope you get in.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: For some reason, there's no record of any of it.
examples.ja: それが、何の記録も残ってないんだよ。

examples.en: I heard that Kitayama-san is a world record holder in swimming!
examples.ja: 北山さんって、水泳の世界記録保持者なんだって！

examples.en: This book contains testimonies from Japanese soldiers who decided to remain in Palau even after the Pacific War had ended.
examples.ja: この本には、太平洋戦争終了後もパラオに残ることを決意した日本兵の証言が記録されています。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Write down</kanji> a <kanji>record</kanji> of the events so we have a <vocabulary>record</vocabulary>, please. Don't want people to forget about this momentous occasion, when King Felix got his perfect game.

記録 refers to the act of putting something on record or to the record itself. Just like English "record," it can also refer to the best performance or most remarkable event of its kind that's been officially measured and noted, like the record for fastest baseball pitch.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Are you playing army? That looks fun. Let me in too.
examples.ja: 軍隊ごっこをしているの？面白そう。私も入れてよ。

examples.en: I do not believe that there is any country that does not need to have an army.
examples.ja: 私は、軍隊を持つ必要の無い国は存在しないと思っています。

examples.en: Many men of this generation have military experience.
examples.ja: この世代の男性は軍隊経験がある人が多いんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>army</kanji> <kanji>squad</kanji> is <vocabulary>an army</vocabulary>. It's also just the <vocabulary>army</vocabulary>. It refers more to "an" army rather than "the" army. Just a group of people who do army things.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I was chosen as a member of an advance squad.
examples.ja: 先発隊に選ばれました。

examples.en: What kind of things would I have to do if I became a member of the Tofugu party?
examples.ja: トーフグ隊のメンバーになると、どんなことをしなくちゃいけないんですか？

examples.en: I am the captain of a small animal rescue team.
examples.ja: 私は、小動物レスキュー隊の隊長です。

examples.en: When she was hired by the Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force Band, she didn’t know that she had to physically work out as hard as them as well.
examples.ja: 海上自衛隊音楽隊に採用された時、彼女は他の自衛隊員と同様に肉体的にも厳しいトレーニングを受けなくてはいけないことを知らなかった。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

隊 is commonly used as a suffix to refer to an organized group or unit, often one that works together toward a specific goal or purpose, like a レスキュー隊 (rescue <vocabulary>squad</vocabulary>), 軍の部隊 (military <vocabulary>unit</vocabulary>), or 登山隊 (mountaineering <vocabulary>team</vocabulary>)!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned, probably because this is stuck onto things, describing various squads.

examples.en: This is a soldier ant.
examples.ja: これは兵隊アリですね。

examples.en: The soldiers wandered the woods aimlessly.
examples.ja: 兵隊達は、気の向くままに森を歩いていた。

examples.en: Our sons have recently become really into playing soldiers.
examples.ja: うちの息子達は、最近兵隊ごっこをすることにハマっています。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>soldier</kanji> in a <kanji>squad</kanji> is a real <vocabulary>soldier</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>sailor</vocabulary>, unlike those "soldier" who are not in a squad. They don't have jobs, and can't be called real soldiers.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I finally decided to join the band.
examples.ja: ついに音楽隊への入隊が決まりました。

examples.en: I never thought there would be an interview for the enlistment test.
examples.ja: 入隊試験に面接があるとは思ってもみなかった。

examples.en: Can a Japanese man enlist in the U.S. military?
examples.ja: 日本人男性がアメリカ軍に入隊することはできますか。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Enter</kanji>ing into a <kanji>squad</kanji> is called <vocabulary>enlistment</vocabulary>!

入隊 can refer to <vocabulary>enlist</vocabulary>ing in any group that ends with 隊 (squad), like the 軍隊 (military) or an 音楽隊 (marching band). These are indeed the most common uses.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The pumps I bought over the weekend don't fit properly, and my heels hurt.
examples.ja: 週末に買った靴が合わなくて、かかとが痛むんです。

examples.en: Lately, my mother has often been complaining about her knees hurting.
examples.ja: 母は最近よくヒザが痛むと言っていました。

examples.en: It was heartbreaking to see the bears, emaciated and searching for food.
examples.ja: やせ細ってエサを探し回るクマの姿を見て、胸が痛みました。

examples.en: I've had a bad toothache since last night, so could you check that for me please?
examples.ja: 昨日の夜から歯が酷く痛むんですが、診てもらえますか。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how <ja>痛い</ja> is "painful"? This is the verb version of that, so it means <vocabulary>to ache</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to hurt</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be in pain</vocabulary>.

痛む is an intransitive verb that suggests an ongoing sensation of pain or aching. It's a little more descriptive than 痛い, so you might see it used in writing or to describe a more persistent or recurring condition. It's also often used figuratively, especially in expressions like 心が痛む (my heart aches).
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading, which you learned already!

examples.en: Even though Ms. Matsumoto knows that I am on a diet, she always tempts me to go to a cake shop together.
examples.ja: ダイエットしてるって知ってるのに松本さんはいつもケーキ屋さんに行こうと誘惑してくる。

examples.en: The snake tempted Eve to eat the fruit from the tree of the knowledge of good and evil.
examples.ja: ヘビはイブを善悪の知識の木の実を食べるように誘惑してしまったのだ。

examples.en: She is a devil who seduces many men.
examples.ja: 彼女はたくさんの男を誘惑する悪魔だ。

meaning_mnemonic: If 誘惑 is seduction or temptation, then the verb version would be <vocabulary>to seduce</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to tempt</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know the word 誘惑 first, though.

examples.en: I privately imported cigars from Cuba through the Internet.
examples.ja: 私はインターネットでキューバから葉巻を個人輸入した。

examples.en: Japan imports foods from various countries.
examples.ja: 日本は色んな国から食料を輸入しています。

examples.en: My job is to import wine and chocolate from Europe.
examples.ja: 私はヨーロッパからワインとチョコレートを輸入する仕事をしています。

meaning_mnemonic: 輸入 is <kanji>import</kanji>. Now let's make it a verb. <vocabulary>To import</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know the word 輸入 as well.

examples.en: We won't be able to do anything about this with just our own efforts.
examples.ja: 我々の力だけでは、どうにもならないんです。

examples.en: It can't be helped. I'll try to think of it as our fault for causing it.
examples.ja: 仕方ないです。原因を作った我々が悪いと思うようにします。

examples.en: We cannot condone terrorism.
examples.ja: 我々はテロを容認することはできません。

examples.en: We need to carefully consider the problem.
examples.ja: 我々はその問題を熟考する必要がある。

meaning_mnemonic:
我 is me, so two of me makes <vocabulary>we</vocabulary>! Or <vocabulary>us</vocabulary>!

You've learned that 我 is an old-fashioned pronoun. 我々 is similar in that it feels formal and authoritative. This means it's often used in situations that require official representation, like company statements, business meetings, or political speeches. Check out our context sentences for some examples!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 我, twice.

examples.en: It is seen as having no direct influence on health.
examples.ja: 健康に直接的な影響は無いと見られています。

examples.en: I don't have a direct connection with him, but I could probably get his contact information.
examples.ja: 直接的な知り合いではないんですけど、連絡先なら分かると思いますよ。

examples.en: If possible, please try not to use overly direct language.
examples.ja: できれば、あまり直接的な表現は使わないようお願いします。

examples.en: Fortunately, our family didn't take any direct damage from the huge earthquake or the tsunami in Japan.
examples.ja: 幸運なことに、私の家族はあの日本の大地震や大津波による直接的な被害は受けませんでした。

meaning_mnemonic:
直接 means "direct." Add 的 to the mix and you have <vocabulary>directly</vocabulary>.

This is a relatively formal word, so you'll encounter other words like ダイレクト in more casual contexts.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know 直接 already.

examples.en: It was a very beautiful starry sky.
examples.ja: とっても綺麗な星空でした。

examples.en: Kawaguchi-san's house is always clean and tidy.
examples.ja: 川口さんの家は、いつも綺麗に片付いています。

examples.en: I can't trust people who only say things that sound good.
examples.ja: 綺麗事ばっかり言う人は信じられません。

examples.en: "Salmon, you're the most beautiful woman I've ever met." "Fugu, that's such a lie."
examples.ja: 「君みたいに綺麗な女性に会ったのは初めてだよ、サーモン。」「フグったら、ウソばっかり。」

meaning_mnemonic:
Things that are <kanji>beautiful</kanji> and <kanji>lovely</kanji> are very <vocabulary>beautiful</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>pretty</vocabulary>, and often <vocabulary>clean</vocabulary>, too. You can call someone 綺麗. You can also mention how clean something is with 綺麗. Gives you some insight as to what "beauty" is in Japan, I suppose. Take your baths, folks.

Wondering what the difference is between 綺麗 and 美しい? 美しい is more dramatic, so it implies you’re really blown away by something’s (or someone’s) beauty. 綺麗, on the other hand, is a more everyday word that covers anything that’s beautiful, pretty, or even just clean. In other words, the bar is a bit lower for 綺麗!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It looks like it will rain tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明日は雨が降るみたいですね。

examples.en: It's snowing.
examples.ja: 雪が降ってきたよ。

examples.en: Then at that time, an unexpected stroke of good fortune fell upon us.
examples.ja: そんな時に、思いがけない幸運が降ってきたんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>descend</kanji>, but this word means something closer to <vocabulary>to fall</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to come down</vocabulary>.

降る is commonly used when talking about the weather, like 雨が降る (it rains) or 雪が降る (it snows). It also applies to other things falling from above, like 火山灰が降る (volcanic ash falls) or even figuratively, as in 幸運が降ってくる (good luck comes your way).
reading_mnemonic: The rain is <vocabulary>to fall</vocabulary> and you're outside anyway with your mouth open so you'll get a mouth <reading>full</reading> (ふる) of rainwater! All the ponds, wells, and your yard will be full of water too!

examples.en: I pitched a tent along the edge of the bog.
examples.ja: 沼のほとりにテントを張った。

examples.en: Don't go into the bog. It's dangerous if you fall into it.
examples.ja: 沼に入ってはいけないよ。沼に落ちると大変だからね。

examples.en: Many creatures live at the bottom of the bog.
examples.ja: 沼の底にはたくさんの生き物がいるんだよ。

examples.en: I guess I have to jump into the swamp anyway.
examples.ja: どっちにしろ沼に飛び込まなきゃいけないと思うしね。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Note that, unlike English, which differentiates between different types of wetlands like marshes, swamps, or bogs, Japanese 沼 refers to any pond-like areas with muddy, murky water.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, ぬま.

examples.en: Many wild animals inhabit this marshland.
examples.ja: この沼地には、たくさんの野生動物が生息している。

examples.en: Jeff fell into the marshland and became covered in mud.
examples.ja: ジェフは沼地に落ちて、泥だらけになった。

examples.en: Many swamps are scattered around this area.
examples.ja: この辺りには、多くの沼地が点在している。

examples.en: There's a legend that a dragon lives in the depths of a cave located in the marshland on the outskirts of town.
examples.ja: 町外れの沼地の洞窟の奥には、ドラゴンがいるという言い伝えがあります。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>bog</kanji> <kanji>earth</kanji> place is a place where the earth is boggy. That's a <vocabulary>marshland</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>wetland</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the respective kanji.

examples.en: Do something to halt the enemy's advance!
examples.ja: どうにかして敵の進撃をはばんでくれ！

examples.en: Viet advanced on the enemy.
examples.ja: ビエトは敵に進撃した。

examples.en: I’m hooked on Attack on Titan.
examples.ja: 進撃の巨人にはまっています。

examples.en: Wow, isn't that amazing? That Hanshin Tigers' incredible winning streak! I really hope this momentum continues.
examples.ja: いやー、すごいですね！阪神タイガースの快進撃！この進撃、続いてほしいですね。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>advance</kanji> and <kanji>attack</kanji>! This is a <vocabulary>charge</vocabulary> on someone or something, though it can also be an <vocabulary>advance</vocabulary> on them. Yep, this is the 進撃 from 進撃の巨人, the popular anime and manga. Don't say you never learned anything useful here.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the ones you learned with the kanji. Advance! Charge! Move on to the next item!

examples.en: I'm glad that she is a sensible maid.
examples.ja: 分別のある家政婦さんで良かったよ。

examples.en: After conducting several individual interviews, I decided on this housekeeper.
examples.ja: いくつか個人面接をしてこの家政婦さんに決めました。

examples.en: I am a nanny, not a housekeeper.
examples.ja: 私はナニーなんで、家政婦とは違います。

examples.en: I think we should hire a housekeeper.
examples.ja: 家政婦を雇おうかと思っているんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
The person who <kanji>govern</kanji>s your <kanji>house</kanji> like a <kanji>wife</kanji> is your <vocabulary>housekeeper</vocabulary>.

Note that it's common to use the polite honorific さん when talking about a 家政婦さん!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Do you have cousins?
examples.ja: 従兄弟はいますか？

examples.en: What I am most looking forward to in Japan is meeting my cousins.
examples.ja: 日本で一番楽しみなのは、従兄弟に会うことです。

examples.en: For Halloween, I went to Universal Studios Japan with my cousin.
examples.ja: ハロウィンは、従兄弟と一緒にUSJに行ってきました。

examples.en: Cousins can get married?!
examples.ja: 従兄弟同士は結婚できるんだぜ。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 兄弟 means "siblings?" Well when they're siblings you have to <kanji>obey</kanji> they're not your brother or sister, they're your <vocabulary>cousin</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The entire reading for this is an exception. Sorry about that. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

What are the two defining traits your cousin has? They're good and a child. いいと子, or <reading>いとこ</reading> for short. Just remember your good, kid cousin. Your いとこ cousin.

examples.en: I've longed to be in the derby and want to win no matter what it takes.
examples.ja: 憧れのダービー、なんとしても勝ちたいです。

examples.en: He's someone I admire.
examples.ja: 彼は私の憧れです。

examples.en: Being a WaniKani engineer is everyone's dream job.
examples.ja: ワニカニのエンジニアは、みんなの憧れの仕事です。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>long for</kanji> something you'll get feelings of <vocabulary>yearning</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>longing</vocabulary>. Don't worry, some day you'll get whatever it is. 

憧れ can also describe a strong feeling of <vocabulary>admiration</vocabulary>, particularly for people.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

examples.en: I'm on the beach right now doing an Instagram live.
examples.ja: 今、浜辺でインスタライブしてまーす。

examples.en: Look! I found a cherry blossom shell on the beach!
examples.ja: 見て！浜辺でサクラ貝を見つけたの！

examples.en: Shall we take a walk on the beach?
examples.ja: ちょっと浜辺を歩きませんか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>beach</kanji> <kanji>area</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>beach</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic:
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 辺 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>Beach</vocabulary> starts with <reading>be</reading>. Be is べ! (I mean, it's pronounced differently, but they're spelled the same!) When you think of the beach, think of べ!

examples.en: The reason is that tomorrow is the cut-off date for my credit card.
examples.ja: 何故なら、明日がカードの締め日だからです。

examples.en: The reason is simple: it's because it tastes good.
examples.ja: 理由はシンプルで、何故なら美味しいからです。

examples.en: It's because you should use your waiting time more productively.
examples.ja: 何故なら、待ち時間は有益に使った方がいいからです。

examples.en: Because, he was a wizard!
examples.ja: 何故なら、彼は魔法使いだったのです。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is like saying "when it comes to the 何故," which means you're giving a reason, making this <vocabulary>because</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>the reason is</vocabulary>, followed by… whatever you wanna say! 

Note that this is a quite formal way to say "because," so you'll mostly encounter this in writing or formal speech, and almost always at the beginning of a sentence in Japanese.
reading_mnemonic: This reading is an exception but you learned them already because they're the same as the word 何故, which you learned a few levels ago. It just has some kana attached to it!

examples.en: Don't worry! Everyone makes mistakes.
examples.ja: ドンマイ！誰だって間違えることはあるよ。

examples.en: Making a mistake on such a simple question is so frustrating.
examples.ja: こんな簡単な問題を間違えるなんて、悔しいよ。

examples.en: Excuse me, I mistook you for a friend.
examples.ja: すいません、友人と間違えてしまいました。

examples.en: It seems that someone else's child allowance was deposited into my bank by mistake.
examples.ja: 間違えて他人の児童手当が私の銀行に振りこまれていたみたいです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 間違い means "a mistake?" Well this is the verb version. It means <vocabulary>to make a mistake</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to mistake</vocabulary>.

This verb is transitive. That means that it takes a direct object. Bear in mind that this one is a bit tricky, though, because although it's transitive in Japanese, the English translation will sometimes be intransitive.
reading_mnemonic: It's read the same as 間違い! Nice and easy!

examples.en: I'm gonna go move my car.
examples.ja: ちょっと車を移動してくるよ。

examples.en: That person is giving off a bad vibe. Do you want to move places?
examples.ja: なんか嫌な感じだね。場所、移動する？

examples.en: We have to transfer Prince Koichi to a safe place.
examples.ja: コウイチ王子を安全な場所へ移動させなくてはいけません。

examples.en: You get worn out when you migrate long-distance by bus.
examples.ja: バスで長距離の移動は疲れる。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Shift</kanji> and <kanji>move</kanji> to create <vocabulary>movement</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I wonder how long it will take to thaw this turkey.
examples.ja: このターキー、解凍するのにどのくらい時間かかるかな？

examples.en: The defrosting method should be written on the packaging.
examples.ja: パッケージに解凍方法が書いてあるはずだよ。

examples.en: To open this file, you will need a file extractor.
examples.ja: このファイルを開くには、解凍ソフトが必要です。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>untie</kanji> something that's <kanji>frozen</kanji>, you're <vocabulary>thawing</vocabulary> it. The best way to go about <vocabulary>defrosting</vocabulary> anything is always to untie it first.

In the context of computer files, this word can also mean <vocabulary>unzipping</vocabulary>. We unzip files in English, but in Japanese we thaw them!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi for both kanji, so you should be able to read this one on your own.

examples.en: It's been five years since everyone gathered together.
examples.ja: 全員が揃うの五年ぶりだね。

examples.en: The Yamada family's shoes are always neatly arranged.
examples.ja: 山田さんちのクツはいつもきれいに揃っている。

examples.en: All the conditions were met. I couldn't help but feel like we would win.
examples.ja: 全ての条件が揃っていた。もう勝てる気しかしなかった。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb that uses the <kanji>complete</kanji> kanji. It means <vocabulary>to be complete</vocabulary>. It can also be used when you want things <vocabulary>to be uniform</vocabulary>. It feels satisfying to have everything complete and uniform, right?
reading_mnemonic: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned the kun'yomi reading when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this!

examples.en: The North Pole is very cold.
examples.ja: 北極はとても寒いです。

examples.en: Polar bears live in the Arctic.
examples.ja: 北極にはシロクマが住んでいます。

examples.en: In summer in the Arctic, the sky is bright even at night.
examples.ja: 北極の夏は、夜になっても空が明るいんです。

examples.en: I saw the northern lights at the North Pole. It was a very gentle light.
examples.ja: 北極でオーロラを見ました。とてもやさしい光でした。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>north</kanji>ern <kanji>extreme</kanji> of the world is the <vocabulary>North Pole</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>Arctic</vocabulary>. You know, the pole with the polar bears.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses on'yomi readings for 北 (ほく) and 極 (きょく). If you remember those readings, you're almost there — just keep in mind the ほく changes to ほっ in this word!

examples.en: Okay, next we'll do a stretch where you twist your body from side to side.
examples.ja: それじゃあ次は、左右に体を捻るストレッチをします。

examples.en: If you give that switch a hard twist, the engine will start.
examples.ja: そのスイッチを強く捻るとエンジンが入りますよ。

examples.en: There was kimchi in the bread, and everyone looked puzzled by it.
examples.ja: パンの中にキムチが入っててさ、みんな首を捻ってたよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>twist</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to twist</vocabulary>.

捻る literally means "to twist," so you can use it for everything from turning the handle of a faucet to twisting your ankle in a soccer game. When combined with other words, it can also take on metaphorical meanings, such as 頭を捻る (to think hard) and 首を捻る (to puzzle over).
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Your horse happened <vocabulary>to twist</vocabulary> his ankle, and <reading>he neigh</reading>ed (ひね) in discomfort. If it were you who had twisted your ankle, you probably would have screamed or shouted an expletive or something, but it's your horse, so he neighed. Poor guy. Put some ice on that thing for him.

Note that this can also be read as ねじる, though this reading is usually written in kana. While ひねる refers to general twisting — like turning or bending to the side — ねじる tends to have a nuance of twisting something multiple times, like a string or wire, often from both ends.

examples.en: The Halloween party went on until the wee hours.
examples.ja: ハロウィンパーティーは夜更けまで続いた。

examples.en: It puts me in a tough spot when you show up this late at night.
examples.ja: こんな夜更けに来られても困るよ。

examples.en: "Let's meet again!" With those words, Koichi disappeared into the midnight streets.
examples.ja: 「また会おうな！」そう言ってコウイチは夜更けの街へ消えていった。

meaning_mnemonic: We have <kanji>night</kanji> and the noun version of 更ける (to grow late). Stick the two together, and you get a word that means <vocabulary>late at night</vocabulary>, the <vocabulary>dead of night</vocabulary>, or the <vocabulary>wee hours</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You should remember 更's kun'yomi from 更ける, but 夜 is a little tricky because it uses its less common よ reading. You learned this reading with 夜明け, but here's a mnemonic in case you need a refresher:

You've stayed up <vocabulary>late at night</vocabulary> again playing with your <reading>yo</reading>-yo (よ). There are just so many yo-yo tricks you want to master, so you can't help but stay up practicing, yo-yoing until the <vocabulary>wee hours</vocabulary> every night. Someone ought to take that thing away from you so you can get some sleep.
